number of helpful: 178 of 252 people (71%) found this review helpful17 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
												Firstly I would like to say that this game is not all that bad when compared to the other RTS games out there at the moment, however for the fans of Sup Com and Forged Alliance this game is a great dissapointment. There are a great many changes and the entire game feels rushed and less smooth than the previous two, here are a few reasons why.The complex tech trees: Gone. You now start with one tier of unit and minimal choices. Some people prefer this over higher tier units smashing the lower tiers but its simply a lazy option taken instead of actually balancing the different tiers.The choices between different commander upgrades: Gone. Research will give you all the upgrades there is no choice involved.The fine balance between extracters and power and the need to control enough deposits: Gone. Pump out those generic one tier generators and you will recieve far more mass from them than deposits. There is nothing to be gained by pushing out to control a majority of the map simply turtle it out behind your shields (we'll get to those in a moment) and stock up on units/arty/nukesThe careful construction of defences and shields for maximum overlap protection: Gone. Spam those shields as close as possible and you can hold off the world. There are some small differences between the different races shields but they all can still all build as many as they want without even thinking about an efficent base design.The unique racial differences and strengths and weaknesses: Gone. First designer "hey guys are we going to make the units and structures have different statistics like the first game and have counter intelligence options for complex game strategy?" Design lead "nah screw that it sounds complicated, make all the shields and other structures have identical stats and get rid of the other stuff". Very dissapointing since the units from the first game were so unique but now there is no difference in choosing one faction from another.The detailed textures and environments that made it a great looking game: Gone. Its extremely unusual for a series to have a large gap between a game and its sequal and to not improve the graphical quality, this bucks the trend and goes backwards.Well organised unit co-ordination, grouping and movement: Gone. Walking into each other, spinning on one spot trying to collect something right beneath themselves and refusing to move are now the norms.There are more but to be honest I've got to go purge this game from my memory by playing Forged Alliance so this will have to do.

number of helpful: 75 of 103 people (73%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												As a stand-alone game it is amazing. But compared to the previous to Supreme Commander games this is a major step down. Remember how there were huge tech trees? such as the tier one factory can upgrade to the teir two which unlocked more units, well thats all gone. Instead now you build a research station which slowly gains research points which you use to upgrade your units not unlock new ones. Remember how you could choose a commander to start the game with? well now it is story based so you have to play the commanders in order (UEF, AEON the Cybran). Explosions are amazingly downgraded aswell. Remember the satisfaction of destroying a commander and watching a huge nuclear blast spread and destroy their base? Well now the commander explodes in a small blast and and all the oppents units die at once. Also all of the experimental units are extremely nerfed remember the AEON saucer? now it is smaller and much weaker, send 7 intercepters at it and it's gone. The Cybran spider bot has been turned into a crappy little beetle bot which are so easy to defeat they're in the first mission. All shields are the same size now (small, unless your counting huge UEF shield in the DLC) and instead of them all blocking shots the Aeon and Cybran shields let 15% of shots through! and now all shields look the same aswell. But the most annoying thing, the most annoying thing of them all is that everything you build counts as a unit. No more unlimited turrent defences, no unlimited shield protection and no more complex base defences. If you're reading this review before buying the previous games then buy this game first or dont buy it at all

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												I don't really like leaving negative reviews but this is one of those rare occasions where I really regret buying a game. The first Supreme Commander was perfect, an absolutely brilliant game and so was Total Annihilation before that. But Supreme Commander 2 just doesn't cut it. The game feels unfinished. There are only a few units and buildings per faction with no tech tiers or special functions. Graphically it is not as good as the previous game and the rehaul on the factions unit styles is just simply strange... like the cybran giant fire-breathing lizard with robotic limbs.The maps are tiny and the lack of units literally means the only strategy available is to hurl a constant wave of bots at the enemy. The campaign is also lacking. They've attempted to add more of a back story through a series of overly cheesy and annoying cutscenes and comms dialogue. You don't get the epic sense of scale that was previously seen in the first Supereme Commander.All-in-all, if your hoping for a newer version of Supreme Commander 1, I'm sorry but it's not this.

												A lot of people say that this game is too simplistic, and I admit that compared to the first Supreme Commander it is far less complex; however, Supreme Commander 2 does offer a streamlined entrance into the RTS genre for new players or a relaxing and explosive experience for veterans. Overall, this game probably isn't for the high-skill, intense matches that come from other RTS titles like StarCraft 2, but that doesn't mean it can't be fun in its own right. I would heartily recommend this for anyone looking for something easy to get into and fun to play, especially if you've got friends to play it with.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This is my personal favorite RTS.  It definitely has a more intense feel than other similiar RTS games, such as SupCom 1 and Total Annhilation.  The overal strategy is a little smaller in scale, but this leads to faster battles that are more fun to watch.  It's still far more of a macro game than something like Starcraft, but it's one where you can still watch the units vs being zoomed out the entire time like it's predecesor.  It's campaign is plenty fun and playing on hard can be a good intro to skirmish matches.  In additon to traditional multiplayer matches, co-op vs the ai is very fun and challenging as well.  I also highly recommend the DLC, it adds many new units and research options.

content:
Posted: February 10
												Edit 3: Unskippable credits...screw youEdit 2: Final mission bugged out for me. Just didn't progress and got stuck in "cutscene"...yay. RESTART! ♥♥♥♥ this. How about a quicksave feature? No? Grrrrrr.Edit: It's not a bad RTS, just a bad Supreme Commander in my opinion. If you like good RTS games, buy this, if you want Total Annihilation, buy Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance.I'm sad to see this series go down the drain...They've pretty much replaced everything that made Total Annihilation and later on Sup Com a unique experience with boring run of the mill gameplay. Let's go into detail:- The campaign: Again 6 missions for the 3 factions, following 1 storyline, which is basically good, since Sup Coms campaign mode just had 3 different endings for the same war. The animation quality of the cutscenes is, however, somehow worse than in Sup Com 1 or FA. The missions, so far, are extremely bland. I've completed 5 of the 6 UEF missions and I'm barely 2 hours in the game. In Sup Com 1 it took me that long to even beat the first 1 or 2 missions, since the battlefield would constantly be expanding after achieving your objectives (which could screw you over big time). This time around, the first mission takes 10 minutes...I♥♥♥♥♥♥you knot. Mission 5 was 25 minutes and I chilled. All the epic from epic battles has been siphoned straight out of this campaign. I'm sure this is not such an issue in MP, but I don't know how big those maps are.- The economy: They've ♥♥♥♥ing "revamped" the economy system...or rather they've dumbed it down...what made TA and Sup Com 1 so unique WAS their economy system. You had income and spending. If you spent more than you earned, you would slowly lose accumulated resources, until you hit rock bottom and your economy would tank. Things would still be completed, just slower. That was good. Wanna build a ♥♥♥♥ing mega artillery with 10 builders? Be prepared to have unlimited resources or face the consequences. On the other hand, you had a clear build path, and once your economy got going, say hello to mass production...you know, how it should be...in a damn war. In Sup Com 2 you instead gather resources automatically, but you can only spend those you actually HAVE. Like in Starcraft for example. Hey, this building or unit costs 1000 mass and 2000 energy, better wait till you've accumulated that before anyone starts building...♥♥♥♥ this.- Builders and plants: In Sup Com 1 you could assign several builders for 1 building, thus speeding up construction time if you had a good economy. Now only 1 builder may build at a time. At least you can still have them support the unit plants...for no additional cost by the way. Mass producing units also doesn't seem viable anymore since, at least in the early campaign missions, it's impossible to produce enough to actually create a massive army of 400 or so units...- Buildings: The number of buildings has been substantially reduced. Right now I have access to a mass extractor, an energy collector a research facility, land, air and naval base, a radar station, a sonar station, a shield generator and 2 defensive structures for land and air...yay. That is the amount of buildings Sup Com 1 had as Tier ONE. The tier system is gone by the way. Just build 1 construction plant and it can build everything.- Units: Same as buildings. There are only about 5 land units, 3 air units, 3 naval units and experimentals, which are for the most part rather "meh". Building an experimental in Sup Com 1 was a serious commitment and its loss was a devastating blow. On the other hand, these ♥♥♥♥ers could almost eradicate entire armies or bases on their own if the enemy did not have a valid counter. Remember the spider bots? Oh man...the megaliths the Cybrans have now are just a sorry excuse. The UED Fatboy II is a lot weaker than the original Fatboy, has no shields, no hit points and can't produce anyunits. What happened? Did they just forget how to build the good stuff after 25 years of peace? The UEF King on the other hand is a fun experimental...way too strong. Where is the balance here? I think it's good to diversify the factions more, but you shouldn't do so at the expense of complexity. Where are my patrolling air scouts? Where are my almost impossible to hit interceptors? Where are my T3 missile turrets? Where are my nuclear power plants? Where are my BRICKS!? Where are my almost indestructible warships? And my heavy gunships? Why do my air units hover in the air when they're not engaging enemies? And why are they swarming in a 1 by 1 area around each other when they are fighting? And why are they only flying at 10 meters above ground? Why don't they have to resupply anymore? That was cool!Interface: It's cleaner, but also more generic and sorely lacking tool tips. What does a Poseidon battleship do? No idea. What's the range? Does it have AA? Does it have torpedoes? Apparently yes, but the game doesn't tell you. There are less options here and I don't like it all that much.Research: Instead of building up your base, you now continously earn research points with which to unlock new buildings and units, improve your existing units (with personal shields or more damage for example), reduce build times or improve your ACU. A shallow system you have to deal with in every mission and match from the very beginning again. You building the biggest experimental units now just takes about 15 minutes maybe.Combat: This is actually the best part about the game. Units move effortlessly and don't get in the way of each other. No excessive "rat's tails" as far as I can tell. Animations and ordinance looks good. It's fun to watch...BUT!Graphics: What the ♥♥♥♥ were they smoking? They've replaced the somewhat gritty graphics from Sup Com 1, which were a nod to Total Annihilation, with some sort of cartoony mess. The UEF forces are bright blue and yellow with VERY little detail on them (apart from weapons fire, which looks great). They look like LEGOs for ♥♥♥♥s sake. The Cybrans are this yellow smudge of vomit, instead of the imposing black and red with the circuits on the ground, the GAAT gun laser towers, etc. It's a disgrace really. Supreme Commander Dostya would not approve...and neither do I.Oh Sup Com 2, what you could have been...if you want to experience this 90s era gameplay, play Sup Com: FA (it's a lot better than the base game and most mechanics actually work). And then play Total Annihilation and rejoice!DOSTYA OUT!!!

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
A bit about the game and developers.Supreme Commander 2 is a great robotic strategy game developed by Gas Powered Games and published by Square Enix.Gas Powered Games are also developers of Demigod, original Supreme Commander and so on and on, while Square Enix is a publisher of many published games like Tomb Raider, Hitman, Sleeping Dogs and others.About Gameplay.Supreme Commander 2 is a strategy game with three different factions. Each faction has its own units. Each Faction has its own bonuses. UEF have strongest unites, most expensive units and units with most HP. Cybran Nation are the weakest but the least expensive. They take the least amount of time to construct and are always largest in numbers. Aeon Illuminate are the most balanced units. Their HP and attack strength fits perfectly with the price of the unit and the construction time. There's one more faction in this game, but since it's unplayable I don't think they are too important.The game has both single player and multiplayer mode. In single player your objective is, of course, to save the world. The story is pretty good but nothing too special. The awesome thing about this game is the multiplayer. Since the game is about 2-3 years old the servers are very empty. And those that have players are usually professionals and games with them lasts about five to ten minutes. There's tones of strategies you can do to win this game. I played a lot of skirmish games to learn a lot about this game.To be able to play this game correctly you need to  learn fast. Because even AI is so smart that it can win against you on normal difficulty. It will attack you from all possible directions: water, air and land. It will attack in small waves while slowly building a huge wave of army. The AI is amazing.It has three different resources. Mass, Energy and Research. You can set up research facilities and energy builders where ever you want, but you can only place Mass on a designed area. Players can fight against each other to be able to own the Mass builders that they need.You need Mass and Energy to be able to build new units and structures, while you need research points to be able to research for new units, more HP or new building that will help you with who knows what. You need to make sure to always have enough of each, but you also need to make sure that you're able to make a big amount of units since this game is all about large scale wars.As mentioned before, this game is all about large scale wars.  In my opinion best tactic is to play with two friends. One person focuses on land units, second on water and third on air. That way you can have biggest army numbers due to smallest cost of units. There are two main game types, annihilation and score points. In annihilation your objective is to kill enemy commanders while in score points your objective is to gather as main points as you can by taking over couple of big towers.Graphic and AudioGraphic is great! Lasers and rockets everywhere, blown up robots, massive explosions. It's very well made. Details on the units are also extremely nice! Songs are very quiet and calming, but for the most of the time you're so focused on the action and all the lasers that you barely even hear it.Pros, cons and final grade.Pros:- Wonderful graphic.- Amazingly fun skirmish.- Huge scale battles.- Very fun if you have a friend or two to play against the AI.Cons:- No players so there are barely any multiplayer games.Overall grade: 7/10Extra info: If you're big mech fan as I am, and if you love strategy games, this game is for you. It doesn't involve much thinking, but it's extremely fun to play. Though, don't count on Gundam units to be in this game. Sadly there are no units looking like Gundam ones, hehe.Thank you for reading my reviews! Don't forget that I'm usually posting new reviews on my blog weekly and you can check them out here:[/b] http://midnightwolfie.blogspot.comThank you![/b]

number of helpful: 68 of 110 people (62%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 2, 2014
												As a fan of the original Total Annihilation series I liked what the old Cave Dog group did, Supreme Commander and Forged Alliance were good enough, but Sup Com 2 does not do the franchise justice at all. It is a very dumbed down version which replaces many of the original’s mechanics with research grinding rather then building up bases and getting more advanced units. Basic units are just that, basic they are very boring and very small versus the levels and other units, while you can upgrade them with various research items to make them more effective it does a very poor job at replacing the 3+1 unit tier levels from the previous games. With this game now more then ever you rely heavily on the experimental units rather then building up a force of mixed units of various tiers with maybe one or two X units in the mix.The main campaign does a good enough job at some kind of a story and MOST of the missions are gradual in their difficulty and challenge. However that difficulty spikes abnormally high when you reach the final 4 to 6 missions of the Cybran and you will fail multiple times before you figure out what the developers wanted you to do. The skirmish AI and the AI in general tends to cheat and does so pretty obviously, getting clear stat, research speed, mass and energy boasts right off the bat, even on normal difficulty, which is a shame because I always enjoyed the TA/SC skirmish games. I had shied away from buying this game when it came out after hearing reviews that it was a very basic and stripped version designed for mostly console play so I avoided it until 2013’s Christmas sale. I am glad I did because as much as I really wanted enjoy this game and get just as much play out of it as I did with Sup Com/FA and Total Annihilation it would seem that that is not the case. This will be one of the few games that I have purchased that will not last long on my hard drive, possibly to make room for something more worth while.If you really want to continue to the story of Sup Com and FA, then by all means buy it when it’s on sale again, but do NOT buy this if you were a fan of TA or SC/FA. This honestly makes me worry about what Planetary Annihilation will be like which I hope will not be the case.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												This is a very playable and beautiful game, but unlike it's predecessor, it lacks creativity, is oversimplified and lacks depth and has such a WAAK storyline. It does lack the finesse of Supremme Commander 1 and Forged Allaince which I think are the bees knees...Whats more, I dont think that the people who developed it balanced the units particularly well, specifically the experimentals, I have no idewa why anyone would prefer to use a 'chicken egg' aeon unit as oppose to an Anomium (however u spell the AA exp)or UC  because it is rubbish, whats more the megalith aint that great either.  And then, why give the Aeon the AA exp (which can be taken down by 10-15  gunships) and give cybran the soul ripper, which is quite powerful (air unit) and give the UEF the terror exp thingy and no aa unit, I just think, as I read about Watch dogs earlier, that this dev crew have cut and pasted and not thought too much about what they were doing... (supcom 1 avoided this by making 3 tech levels which when paired with sheilds all races ahd would give each exp a very good run for it's money in defence, let alone the asfs, to the regular t1 intcepeteors)... regardless, I am not quite convinced that they did a great job of this, I admit perhaps i should throw each of them up against each other in a few skirmishes.Economy wise, yes it's like any other standard industry modelled strategy game other than the original which really doesn't work well when making experiementals, i.e.unless you are have money coming out of all orifaces,  your smaller factories will keep hoarding the resources whilst the exp factories etc will sit there doing nothing.  Yes... maybe there is some skill and attetnion to be paid to this problem, but this just makes a simple game into one of those tedious complex games that the Dev's clearly wanted to avoid, when going back to the drawing board from Supcom 1 and they way supcom 1 handled it was far more elegeant!Now , the research.  Well it has been done before, and it doesn't feel right, for a start, it kills the pleasure of killing and killing and getting better - veterency.  making your commander and exps mortal and very lacking even when some noob throws rubbish units at u time after time (though the mass income normally makes that worth it).  And yes, creating more research centre makes it easier...  But, after all that, research centres are rendered useless after all research is complete,  making a practical investment in those centres very short sighted strategy wise. End point is , research in the long run feels pointless.I suppose the research tree does make it easier for noobs who can look over their options, although restrictive trees dont necessarily do this, but the idea of upgrading lots of things on units is fun! even the ACU upgrades have been done away with in favour of this tree, so there is no choice, it's the capitalist idea, get resources and buy everything, boring! :(Also , as this is a Square Enix game, just as you would find the same smell about a 2K game or a UBIsoft game, so you do so with the airy fairy Square ENIX... shame, so many games are gutted and strung up by these awful mass companies, they should just let the real professionals get on with it!TRololol, this is worth playing on a weekend off, but it doesn't have anywhere near the life of a good  game would and defintely no where near it's predicessor!

number of helpful: 9 of 9 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24
												A good strategy game for beginner-intermidiate players. The futuristic campaign is not bad for a RTS, and offers a good challenge on harder difficulties. The three factions do not vary much in strategy in the early game though their mid to late tier units offer unique game changing opportunities from the brutal to the subtle. Thanks to a simple but effective interface, the game is also easy to play.  Skirmish/Multiplayer is a profound improvement to its Xbox 360 counterpart, having good pre-game options and a variety of maps and 4v4 compatibility (though the game's speed will definitely suffer with 5+ players). AI difficulty is reasonably balanced with customizable strategies for them to use. Internet connectivity in PvP multiplayer is typically not a problem either.Unlike its predecessor, Supreme Commander 2 is less complicated and therefore game sessions are typically quicker though long, protracted battles are still possible with the huge 500 unit cap and available rush timers. More experienced players may become bored by the lack of diversity in strategies that limits replayability, as many battles (especially against AI) hinge on simply building a ton of one super unit or another. The DLC adds some interesting units and buildings though.Overall a good value for a RTS fan or newbie looking to try somethings new, but not the most robust experience out there.

												Did you like Supreme commander, building your base, getting a massive army ready to go face to face with the enemy, or just turtle up and use heavy long-range artillery and nukes to destroy your enemy? Me 2, but lets face it, supreme commander was a game that required at least 2-6 hours of time for just one game. Sadly this game is not so active anymore online, but if you've got a few strategy loving friends on your list, you could most likely pick this up for a bargain on sale, and have a blast.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												Genre - Sci-Fi RTSI only played this game recently after tying out Planetary Annihilation but finding it too complex for quick games, and I found this game similar in some respects but a lot more accessible. I have played several skirmish games, co-op and 6 missions of the main campaign. You have Land, Naval and Air units to build and research upgrades for. There are three major factions to choose from that are diverse but balanced in most aspects. You need to build up fairly quick and get mixed units to be effective. You fight in a Giant Mech that once destroyed loses you the game. The units are varied enough and the game is enjoyable in quick bursts.It seems to me to be the natural follow up to Total Annihilation, an old RTS game that received a lot of praise back in my day.  It is the first decent RTS I have played since Starcraft 2. Don't get me wrong with the comparison at the start though, Planetary Annihilation is also fun but when you are fighting across planets and using orbital platforms it gets very confusing, very fast. However, once you have graduated Supreme Commander 2 school and want more of a challenge, I would try that next. As for me I am happy being a Supreme Commander.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												Significantly downgraded from the first Supreme Commander, number 2 nevertheless has a great story. But no matter how great the story, the gameplay has been drastically reduced. There was nothing like rolling over your enemy with hundreds of tanks or blasting them to oblivion with hundreds of bombers. Now that is impossible. A severe poulation limit reduction and minimal unit variation creates a rather sucky knock off of the first game. The number of different units have been much reduced. Basic tanks. Basic Walkers. Basic flyers. Worse still, Mega Units have been dummed down to be nothing less then weak. They no longer strike fear into the hearts of your enemies, but are merely a nuisance.I heard the developer wanted us to feel closer to the characters. I hate them all. Supreme Commander Forged Alliance however: I was genuinly angry when Dostia died. Buy this game if its on sale (99p). Otherwise, don't waste the 3 hours it takes to beat it. Go for Forged Alliance if you want the next step in the story.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2016
												I am a huge strategy buff, and let me tell you, I have had a hard time finding a game that aces the RTS feel like SC2. I have nearly 500 hours in the game and have been playing it for what feels like forever. Especially when you combine the origonal in-game content with the DLC (I think its like $5 or something, theres no reason not to get it), you have such a fantastic range of buildings and units, affording you so much in the way of letting you pick your strategy.The maps are fun and interesting, if maybe a little static, and a few really push you into a specific, predictable strategy, but every RTS game ive ever played has those. The factions are very nice as well, each having the ability to suit multiple different play-styles, but they do certainly favor certain play styles. For instance, UEF favors highly armored, slow moving but hard hitting units, whereas the Cybran favors a huge mass of highly mobile assault bots, but can also bring some impressive gargantuans into play. The Illuminate favor a heavy tech tree, improving their units with research, as well as having some intense buildings and upgrades that can make them a force to be recconed with late game.The game was pretty intense for its time, but I feel that hardware has definatly caught up to the software SC2 is running. I have a GTX 1060 with 3 internal GB, with 16 external sticks to back it up, and I can run everything on max even late game.Now, my primary complaint with SC2 is that it has what I feel doesnt offer the HUGE, MASSIVE armies, capping players at 500 units, to include buildings as well as units. Most typically, I feel that it really doesnt bother me most times unless its very late game, or I am playing Cybran. If the game had a feature that allowed me to modify the unit count, this game would be 10/10.TL;DR: SC2 is a fantastic RTS, killing alot of modern RTS games IMO. The mechanics are super solid and the game works really well. Awesome game.9.5/10

I always loved Total Annihilation, then the original SupCom.This is a bit different, the pre-build system isn't as versatile nor is the cost management. content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
												By itself, it's not such a terrible game.  It's kind of like starcraft with a strategic view, which is actually pretty cool.  But it is not what I would expect to follow a game like Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance.  Many of the models and names of the units in the game are similar to the previous game, but the scale of SupCom 1 is completely lost and having an upgrade system is against the heart of how Supreme Commander 1 was interesting.  It makes me thing that they were trying to compete with the player base of starcraft instead of creating an actual second game in the line of Total Annihilation and Supreme Commander (Supreme Commander was touted by the devs as the 'spiritual successor' of Total Annihilation, and I consider the first one successful in that regard, but the second, not so much).

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30
												This game is a great followup to one of the best RTS games ever made (absolutely no bias). To people who like Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, this game is recognizable to the previous game, but takes a number of liberties, which distinguish it from the original, but not nesesarily for the better. These changes include the removal of the Teir system in favor of a research tree (similar in a way to Civilization), the nerfing of Expirimental Units, and the removal of the resource-stream in favor of a more traditional stockpile system. These changes may rub the wrong way with diehard fans of the original (understandably), but they all work together to make a cohesive game, with nothing really feeling left out.  I do not think the game is really better than the first for this, but just different  . If anything is really better because of these changes, it is the accessability of the game.  The game is much more straitforward to understand for a newcomer  , and ends up forming a cohesive, understandable, and much more simple whole. The one thing about Supreme Commander 2 that really shines above the original, is it's simplicity.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												I honestly do not know why this game gets bad reviews as it does from some people. But i absolutely love it. Actually i like it better then Forged Alliance. While Forged Alliance did have some nice bonuses as to putting more then one engineer on a building process and some other things, This game is abit better and more organized in my opinion. In Forged Alliance, to build an Experimental you had to use 1-10 engineers to build it on a random plot of land. In SC2, you can make them from factories. I for one like that instead of random plots of land. Other things i am sad to see go were the Support Armored Command Units. They were very useful but i wont that ruin my gameplay fun!The research is a nice add on, limits and makes things more complicated and more advanced. Not to mention very very challenging. Forged alliance was easy once a good base was set up, in SC2, it keeps you active and on alert for a surprise attack.Another interesting challenge is defending against the Nukes! First time i played it, i was torn apart! But i eventually found a way to defend against 5-6 nukes every 3-5 mins. People also mention units move slow...Actually, they don't. They are 100% the same as Forged Alliance.Pros:- Good System of Units- New Land, Air and Naval Units- New Structures- New way to acquire Mass and Energy- Challenging- A cool research system that provides complexity- Keeps you on alert and not underestimating the AI- Interesting Campaign and Storyline- Good Multiplayer System- New and Cool Maps to play on- Better Graphics- Better Quality- Less Laggy then Forged Alliance when building huge hoards of unitsCons:- Some classic Units from Old games were removed (Not that it is important!)- Only one engineer per building instead of many that could build one building in Forged Alliance- No SACUs- Some Useless Units, but it doesn't affect the gameplay at all- A little to frequent in Nuke Launching by AI and the # of Nukes is abit to high per strike. (Can be defended if done correctly)So in conclusion, I would recommend the game to all my friends and surely say, it would be a great purchase and you will have tons of fun and will keep you active for a good time !

Posted: August 19, 2016
												I had great hopes for this game back when it was announced. It had big shoes to fill considering how excellent Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance was. However, everytime I play this game it makes me want to go back and play Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance (SC:FA) instead. Pros:-Some cool experimental units-Some good art design-The level design is engaging-Characters are more fleshed out compared to previous onesCons:-Everything has been dumbed down-Economy has completely changed from the SC exp: can't spend energy and mass at a deficit-Interface is worse than SC:FA-Gone are the grand battles involving 250+ units-Much smaller scale than SC:FA-Tier system is gone and replaced with research-Unit variety-Maps don't come close to the size of a 64x64 SC:FA map-Cybran ACU looks awfulGPG Changed most of what made the previous SC games so great. The complexity and scale are defining characteristics of the series. Lacking these characteristics, the game falls flat. If a Supcom 3 is ever made it needs to go back to Supcom 1 and FA for influence not Supcom 2. I don't recommend this game if you are a fan of SC: FA.IF you haven't played SC:FA you need to forget this game and get go get SC:FA

content:
Posted: February 23
												I was already planning on getting the game before it went on sale but the moment my friend told me it was less than four dollars I got the game and the DLC for it instantly. I already played it a lot on Console and wow what a leap in gameplay it makes on PC.Some people say that the game sucks, mainly when compared to the original. Sure it has some things cut back from the first instalment but to be fair nobody has hours upon hours to plan a date with their opponent even when the game is sped up. Here in Sup Cop 2 it is far easier for one to pick up and start playing and doesn't take a year to get anything built.To be honest there is no "Better" option between Sup Com 1 and 2. Both are really good games even for their age and both deserve some playtime. Sup Com 1 is more for people that have a thing for more in-depth RTSs and that have a lot of time on their hands where as Sup Com 2 is more for people that are either new to the genre or that want to have some "quick" skirmishes.The DLC is very much worth it for the new things that are added and the new assortment of maps (but it is not needed to enjoy the game) on top of massive map pool to begin with.Don't listen to the haters of Sup Com 2 simply because "It's not as good as Sup Com 1." because really it's subjective. Both are good in their own ways.The Campaign is alright, some cheesy classic bad guy stuff but it's tolerable and a good place to get the hang of the game.I enjoyed the crap out of it on Console way back when so even tho it says (at this point in time) that I only have 11 hours played, trust me that I have far more than that.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2011
												The stars of the first Supreme Commander weren’t the massive experimental units, for the most part. There were three tiers of deathbots before you got to those, each five times more massive, devastating and expensive than the last. It was about building dozens of factories, and streaming out enough deathbots to dominate enough of the map to produce enough mass to afford the next tier up. Then: stream out more.On a 25 square kilometer map, that’s just a very satisfying, physically simulated version of a normal RTS. On a 6,561 square kilometer map, it’s an apocalypse. Your mind goes into overdrive trying to manage eighteen separate assault groups, balance and defend dozens of income sources while ramping up production to meet your snowballing wealth.But throughout it all, the game takes care of the boring stuff for you: units defend themselves intelligently while moving, they organise themselves in optimal formations and stay in them come hell or high water.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Supreme Commander 2 is a Real Time Strategy game, where you build bases, collect resources and make an army, to destroy the enemy base."How much more complicated could that be?", you may ask.Well, if you think that you will easily win by having more tanks and more power than your enemy, you might be right,at times however.I enjoyed this game because it was quick and simple to learn.I also enjoy how beautiful this game CAN look.At times I found that some things were abit clunky or cartoonish.Nonetheless, this game is great.The single player campaign does not have the best story, if I am honest, but the skirmish and online gameplay are quite fun.If I had to compare it to the first game, I would say these comparisons:Better:-The graphics-The game is smooth-Resource collection and economy spending makes more sense-The idea of researching makes it easier-Seeing so many things happening at the same time is quite astonishingWorse:-There seems to be less units and buildings because there aren't 3 Tech levels anymore-The maps are much smaller now-Although you can still build massive armies, you seem to be limited to building 500 units AND buildings. How a buildingcounts as a unit, I will never know.Supreme Commander 2 is a good game, which have about the same aspects as the first game.Where there are pros, there are cons that weigh it out which leave it at a slightly neutral stand.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												In short - a more casual version of SupCom 1. Easier to play, but there's much less to enjoy. Good for casual occasional games with friends. Ultimately, it fails as a Supreme Commander's successor, but stands well as a standalone game.Although Supreme Commander 1 was meant to be /the/ strategy game, with large maps and huge unit caps, where build orders gave place to thought-out tactics, it ultimately ended up being a base-building simulator, as people grew to refer to it. Supreme Commander 2 trades the large scales for a tighter gameplay, shifting focus from the base to the units.The units are fewer in variety, each having a distinct role. There is much less fiddling with assembling a perfect mix of the hundreds of different bots, tanks, and airplanes. Choosing your tactics is now more clearly resembling rock-paper-scissors, which is both good and bad, depending on the player.Also, there are only either big badass mother♥♥♥♥ing guns, or cannon fodder. You don't build a tactical missile launcher to fend off your enemies. It's either a small artillery installation, or a nuke. Same with units vs. experimentals.But wait, speaking of experimental units, it's not as black and white. As before, they are pretty much useless alone when facing a critical mass of smaller units. Perhaps even more so than in SupCom 1, you will want to provide escorts to your big guys. Here, they are easier to build and to destroy, but having one early enough can still mean a victory.There is a new resource - Research - gained through battle and boosted by research stations. Tech tiers gave way to global upgrades (purchased with research points) that are applied to all units, buildings, or else - existing and future. This serves to speed up the game, though it takes away from the complexity. Whereas in SupCom 1 destroying an upgraded outpost with tech 3 factories was a big hit, here it doesn't take much to rebuild it. Experiments units are also unlocked with research.Instead of choosing between spending resources on improving your economy/units and building more units, you just do both simultaneously, while spending any excessive mass/energy you have on research stations.Speaking of resources, here you don't get to build mass/energy storages - they are unlimited. Instead of draining your money during construction, the cost is deduced at the beginning of the process. Finally, there are no mass fabricators, and I have never seen someone have a problem with energy, for the reactors are very cheap and effective.There is not much to say of the base. Just as unites, the buildings are also fewer. At the beginning of the game, you are presented with a choice of 8 "normal" structures and one "advanced" - the radar. As you research the upgrades for the structures, you unlock things like artillery, nukes, and others.Engineers now cannot assist each other when building structures (they can, however, assist factories).Everything is built much faster in comparison to SupCom 1 (where 30-minute build times weren't extraordinary, though improved in FA) - you won't find an experimental who takes much more than 3 minutes to build.I haven't completed the story, but from what I played it wasn't incredibly interesting. Perhaps as a tool for honing your skills, it would do.The visual style of the game is nice - it is also simplified, as if to underline the idea the developers had in mind. Similar to Planetary Annihilation - almost a bit cartoonish. Although now outdated and no eye candy at all, it is still pleasant to look at while playing.I would recommend this game to people who want to play a SupCom-esque game with friends, but don't want to take the days to teach them how to play it. It's simple, bright, fun, and fast. There is not much depth to it, but the gameplay is satisfying and victories sweet.Personally, I couldn't stand to play it for more than a few hours a month, as I kept switching to Supreme Commander 1. And if you want a fun match with friends, I would recommend Starcraft 2 over this.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												Basicly a dumbed down version of the original. Interestingly though, it has become a different flavour of the same thing, but they both taste equally good.The game is simple and that makes it interesting, everything is flat and rather straightforward but it works.It suffers from all the flaws the original has. Poor AI, when you can get experimentals .. spam the crap out of them, missions that are only difficult (if at all) for the first 10-ish minutes, etc. However the game plays quite nicelly, it has cheating AI's in skirmish/MP and because of the 'flatness' you do not have to reserve 2+ hours to take down a cheating AI in skirmish or do a single campaign mission. Compared to the original, with 5 (or 6?) mission, it actually has 15 though. That does offer some more variaty in the missions but the overall time you spend on the campaign wont be much longer than you spend doing the campaign in the original.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2015
												Best RTS of all time.The gameplay is addictive, and with a few friends you can unlock the full potential of Skirmish mode.The singleplayer story overall is alright, its short, but offers a sort of background on why the 3 factions are warring. Doesn't take much time to play through but is fun, none the less.The multiplayer is where the gameplay really shines through, there's nothing like having a massive land/nuclear war on Seton's Clutch (map). The interface is simple and easy to get into, overall the game is really simple yet you can spin the gameplay in some many different ways it provides hours and hours of fun. If your really into the game, then thats where the benefits of a modding community come in.My only real complaint is, about the way the addition of mods is so limited. The mods they have out there are amazing, only if it was simpler through say.... the steam workshop to get them. I think this game would still be played by even more people if the game had a larger mod community. But the game does have some great mods that expand the gameplay a ton! If you get this game I reccomend: Supreme Commander 2 0 1 3Revamp Mod For SC2and there are quite a few map packs out there as well. All in all one of my favorite games of all time. Just because of how much variation you can get in gameplay with friends.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												This game has been one my favorite PC games of all time. Whenever im bored or stressed out I always play SupCom2. I have over 500 hours in the game and going for the magic number 1000The gameplay is a lot of fun and it requries careful observation of what your doing but also be able to adapt to your opponents strategy. Unlike other strategy games SupCom2 goes fast. I mean FAST you dont pay attention and you will see yourself having 10000 mass and weak units. A good knowledge of the tech tree and game mechanics is a must.Single player is good for begineers to get their hand on all factions and learn basic mechanics of the game. but the story is a little dry. You'll find you will be spending most of your time online or playing skirmish. Multiplayer is troubling and rewarding. Very few games that you play in Multiplayer will actually be fair games and games are usually less that 30 min. BUT stalemates can last HOURS my longest was 3 hours and the game was so tense. Theres something thrilling about making giant robots shooting each other. The units attack from the land sea and sky. Winning the game isnt that hard either just build the most units as quickly as you can. The hard part is HOW you build those units. Will you build air to counter air? Or anti air units and Bomb Bouncers? Will you push a land force away with magnets or tele to their base. This game desperatlely needs a community and everyday the player count gets less and less everyday I see the same people online too extremely often when only there are 4 lobbies. But playing the game thrilling and rewarding and was the game that got me into PC gaming. I Love Supreme Commander 2

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												An underrated sequel, but still a great game. The graphics and gameplay are solid, and although the experimentals are now 'nerfed' by quite a large margin, they still bring a great sense of power to the battlefield. The research system has been improved and overhauled, adding another level of resource gathering, and leading to more diverse factions than in the previous game. Admitedly, the single player campaign is not the best, and while I enjoyed it, you may see it to be cliche and guessable.But who plays Supreme Commander for the single player?! The skirmish mode and the online are the heart of the game. If this game is on sale, buy it. Note: The multiplayer is quite barren, so get the original Supreme Commander and the dlc as well. The FA forever mod is fantastic for Forged Alliance :)

												An underrated sequel, but still a great game. The graphics and gameplay are solid, and although the experimentals are now 'nerfed' by quite a large margin, they still bring a great sense of power to the battlefield. The research system has been improved and overhauled, adding another level of resource gathering, and leading to more diverse factions than in the previous game. Admitedly, the single player campaign is not the best, and while I enjoyed it, you may see it to be cliche and guessable.But who plays Supreme Commander for the single player?! The skirmish mode and the online are the heart of the game. If this game is on sale, buy it. Note: The multiplayer is quite barren, so get the original Supreme Commander and the dlc as well. The FA forever mod is fantastic for Forged Alliance :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 29, 2012
												I love this game. The units, the buildings, the strategies, the weapons...it's all so amazing. You can look close at a single tank as it fires it's last shot or makes a finishing blow on an experimental. You can pan all the way out to view your entire armies raid enemy bases or die trying. You can build amazing works of machinery called experimentals that can, and I quote, "single-handedly turn the tide of battle." -Manual. If worse comes to worst, you can launch a salvo of tactical nukes at your enemy and pray that they don't have any anti-nuke silos (which is, btw, one of the biggest "lol nope" moments I've ever had).Plus if you play as the Cybran Nation, you can get a fire-breathing dinosaur.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												This is my favroite time based stratagy game. I recommend this game to anyone who plays Company of Heros. There are 3 factions, Illuminent, UEF (United Earth Federation (Ha! Like that would ever happen with the people on this earth)), and Cybran. Each team has a diffrent types of units, buildings, and Commanders. The Commander is your main unit (aka YOU), and with it you can create factories that will produce troops to fight for you.There is also a reserch tree. Each branch (Land, Air, Naval, Commander) helps it with things like shield generators on your units, an escape pod for your commander, or even new units, like the Terror 2000 gunship. It's also has a great campaign. It's even fun to play with bots. Anyone and everyone with some skill will love this game. This game is a must have for all great stratagy players.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												I can understand that players coming over from Supreme Commander and its expansion were disappointed, there are pages upon pages of SupCom players detailing the differences and rightly arguing that the game is less deep and varied. I however am not one of those people.There's a reason why some developers choose to "streamline" their games, and that is to make it inviting to new players. If you're new to these types of large scale RTS titles, then Supreme Commander 2's simplicity is a great way to get used to macro management strategies. for example: i had to adjust my habit of cueing my units up manually, as i would easily get swarmed by the cpu, the solution was to build a factory for each unit type i had and setting it to auto build. The maps are bigger than anything i had ever played and the scale was equally as daunting. Thankfully the streamlined approach of the game made getting used to it far easier and i quickly had fun playing it.As a result i can easily recommend this game to anyone who is just getting started in RTS titles, and more specifically macro management heavy RTS games, this is especially so considering its 14.00 price tag (much less when it goes on sale).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												Literally one of the biggest disapointments in the rts genre i have ever whitnessed. It's like they took supreme commander and watered it down past red alert 2 levels to create the most cookie cutter "game" ever. Gone are the powerfull experimentals, replaced with poor imitations that your ACU can easily defeat alone without any danger. A small handfull of the first tier units can take these out. Gone are the large maps and unit selection. Replaced with tiny zones and only one or two units per element (air, land, sea). You can upgrade them sure, but it still takes away from having to actually do anything strategical whatsoever, in favor of simply unit spamming. The visualls or good; at least for the environment. The unit graphics have been REDUCED substancially. If i had to give this game a score it would be 10%. You can tell right off the bat that no effort was put into this at all and everything became a cop-out black hole of less than mediocrity.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2012
												Supreme Commander 2 is a great game and one of the best RTS that I have played since Age of Empires II. A bit different from Supreme Commander : Forged Alliance, Supcom 2 is smaller in scale, and changes up supply "markets" while still retaining the core idea of "Energy" and "Mass" from the last game. Research is now a resource used to unlock new tech, unlike the last game where engineers were your backbone. Despite these slight changes, Supcom 2 stays true to the aspects which made Forged Alliance good. Not very many people play the online portion as far as I can tell, but if you've got some friends, taking on the AI will be as good a time as any.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												Quick Summary: Real Time Strategy game with huge maps and tons of units in play. If you liked StarCraft or Command & Conquer, you should enjoy Supreme Commander 2.The game has 3 separate single player campaigns all taking place approximately the same time regarding an ancient piece of technology that has been discovered. You play a UEF commander (Human), an Illuminate commander (advanced alien race), and a Cybran commander (cybernetic humans) in the intersecting campaigns, all fighting against factions of the other races, as well as the mysterious Cybran Gauge, who seems to know a lot more about the Shiva Prime technology than anyone else.While the game has similar mechanics to most other Real Time Strategy games, what sets the Supreme Commander series apart is the massive scale of the levels and combat. You have a 300 unit cap and you can really fill the map with units. This is quite a feat because the maps are huge compared to other games like StarCraft or WarCraft. In fact, the maps are so large that you constantly need to zoom out and view the world from a strategic view, otherwise there’s no way you can rely on your minimap to keep an eye on the enemy. Additionally, the research/tech upgrading system is closer to Command & Conquer Generals, where instead of doing your tech upgrades in specific buildings, you access your tech trees in a meta console after you’ve accumulated enough research points. The research points are gained over time from building research buildings or killing enemy units. There are a ton of research options, so you’re unlikely to unlock everything in any given match unless you’re really, really trying.Pros:+Decent, long single player campaigns to get your money’s worth out of the game. Just playing single player will probably take about 12 hours to finish. The multiplayer can occupy even more of your time. +I mentioned the extensive tech tree that you can research, and these options can unlock a number of “experimentals” which are basically huge units that can march slowly across the battlefield kicking♥♥♥♥♥ Each race has their own experimentals to use, some better than others.Cons:-The graphics aren’t anything special. Dawn of War 2, which came out earlier has more convincing gameplay visuals, though the cinematic cutscenes for both these games aren’t all that impressive.-The game is really slow in single player. I don’t mean that the game runs slow on my computer, I mean the game is set to be slow paced and you can’t increase game speed (you can adjust speed in multiplayer). This is especially annoying because of how huge the maps are. If you already know you have enough units to win, you’ll probably want to speed up the game as you’re marching towards the enemy with your huge army.Overall the game is worth a playthrough for the single player campaign, but there are still people playing the multiplayer that you can match with.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												This is strictly an opinion from an old RTS player! First off Supreme Commander 2 takes place after Supreme Commander Forged alliance and that took place after Supreme Commander, so technically this should be Supreme Commander 3, Sadly like most good games and movies the following games are not as good as the original, in this case Supreme Commander 2 does not take place after both precursor Supreme Commanders and is mainly mint for younger players that use no strategy, unlike the old SC's were it took like 2 hours to get nukes and you have long battles, in SC 2 you can get nukes close to within 3 minutes and end the game in 10 minutes, here is a list of things....Pros...........................................................................................1. Good for first time RTS players2. Very basic controls and gameplay (Good for first time players)............................................................................................Cons............................................................................................1. Graphics are very cheesy and are not as good as the first Supreme Commanders2. Story line makes no sense and also does not follow the story’s left off by the other SC's3. Gameplay is too short, like I stated above you can easily win a game in 10 minutes4. Experimental units are to common, unlike the old game were you would freak out because of one in Supreme Commander 2 they are basically just another unit5. cannot build things unless you have the actually amount of energy or mass ( unlike were in the original Supreme Commanders were you could build into the negatives and build slower. in this one you have to have the same amount of energy and mass, this is a disadvantage if your under attack)6. Maps are too small, instead of big maps like in the old SC's the maps are super small in this one and no room to build massive basesSo over all if you’re a 4 year old and want to play this game it is mint for you ( I said this because my 5 year old sister has won all campaigns on normal) But if you are a older RTS gamer and played the other Supreme Commanders and even total annihilation, the precursor to all supreme commanders or any other RTS game this is not the game for you!Rank; 1/10

content:
Posted: July 29, 2011
												Hardcore Real-Time Strategy! That's how you sum up Supreme Commander 2 in this sequel to Chris Taylor's original game. Supreme Commander 2 works out the tedious flaws of the first game while still offering the awesome scale of the so-called "strategic zoom." Supreme Commander 2 caters to traditional and hardcore RTS gamers, so be sure to check it out sometime.Hardcore Real-Time Strategy - Now with DLC! This DLC pack can be enabled/disabled within the game with a simple click of a box so you can game with friends who don't own the DLC, but there's no excuse not to own this pack. It includes new maps and units so be sure to pick it up for the full experience.

Product received for free
												This game quickly became one of if not my favorites after a friend bought it for me. All three factions are different and unique much like their units. Every map is well designed, the game is gorgeous (especially the robots id take one out for a date), you want the game to lag so you can watch the epic end game battle with all of your forces versus the enemies in slow motion. The base building is amazing, and it's sad to see a base go after the games over. This is one of the best real time strategy games out there, and it's a solid purchase along with its dlc, which is a ♥♥♥♥ ton of content so cheap even I can afford it.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												Please note, before reviewing this game, play the god forsaken campeign. It is quite fun, oh yes.THERE ARE NO TECH TIERS, YOU HAVE TO BUILD RESEARCH STATIONS!!!!!!! - Most of the bad reviews are because people come from SC FA, and expect the buildings to be upgradeable. Look harder next time, had to show my friend the research in the top left. He hated this game, and now he loves it. This game has given me many, MANY hours of enjoyment, I would highly reccomened it. It gets very intense very quickly when going agienst difficult opponents.However, there are about maybe ~33% units as much from FA, though you can constanly use all of them, rather than only having a effective few endgame units. They are all upgradeable, with shields, increaced firepower, ETC.The exprimentals are not as powerful as SC FA, but they are FAR cheaper to build!The Maps are smaller, but it makes for more intense and more challenging games. Overall, highly reccd. P.S. If you want bigger maps, the community had made some absolutly massive ones!http://www.moddb.com/mods/revamp-mod/addons/revamp-map-pack-v11

They are all upgradeable, with shields, increaced firepower, ETC.The exprimentals are not as powerful as SC FA, but they are FAR cheaper to build!The Maps are smaller, but it makes for more intense and more challenging games. Overall, highly reccd. P.S. If you want bigger maps, the community had made some absolutly massive ones!http://www.moddb.com/mods/revamp-mod/addons/revamp-map-pack-v11

												A very, very fun RTS, this game is. The gameplay feels nice, the battles don't feel small (and aren't, which is where many RTS' kinda fall flat. Each unit is actually a single unit, unlike many RTS' where the "single" unit is a squad) and the base-building is nice. The story mode is a bit "meh", but this game is fun to play with friends or in a singleplayer Skirmish. The 3 factions all play fairly different, with each getting similar base structures, but completely different units and tech trees. It's a nice game, definitely worth getting if you like RTS games.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Well I have many hours in this game and prob just as many in the first game.  First off SC2 was a trade off in scale to be able to run on the xbox 360 (which is actually a good game if your looking for a good strategy for your console).  But it still has more scale than many other popular RTS games.  The game is far less unit managament and less unit upgrade focused.  You basically pick your attack path at the beginning and off you go, changing from your direction in the game is a bit hard to pull off but with a good teammate it can be done.  The game has great graphics, but unfortunetly it can't take advantage of our awesome new multi-core CPU's we have today, infact it really only uses 1 core and about 20% of a 2nd if you have it, for example the game ran as fast on my 4.2ghz pentium 4 extreme edition as it did on my Q6600 when I got the game years ago.  Gas Powered games is gone now, but just before they were bought up they released a new AI patch which really helped with a lot of the stupidy the AI had, the AI was already challenging but i quickly found a lot of tactics no longer worked against certain levels of enemies.  Faction balance is terrible in the standard game, imo of course, but once you add the DLC the game gets a whole new persective, every faction can now push there attacks in all 4 major ways (naval, air, land, artillery) except Aion who have no artillery.  At the current price point you would be a fool to not pick up the game and the DLC they are completly worth it.  Single player I still need to finish, I have always been terrible about finishing single player in RTS games though :)  If your playing a large multiplayer match or want to get into multiplayer make sure to get some friends going(you use steam to invite into games), and make sure who ever has the most powerful system hosts the game.

												I love SupCom 1. It is the epitomy of a great strategy game. Normally a sequel sets out with the goal of improving on the original without major changes to the formula. Not here; no, not with SupCom 2. Instead, this game is what you get when you take SupCom and gut everything that made it good and dumb down every mechanic. The huge scale, dynamic economy and awesome elite (experimental) units from the first game have all been altered or nixed. Do yourself a favor and avoid this game, especially if you loved the original SupCom.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Faster paced than the original Supreme Commander, but much better if you just want to get a quick match or two in without sitting at the computer all day. Beginner skirmishes take anywhere from 30 mins to an hour, while competitive team matches usually don't run over 15-20 mins tops. This game is particularly fun if you have a friend to play with, either against, or better as an ally against other teams. Strategic gameplay is top notch; there are many options on how you want to advance up the research ladder. It took me awhile to get into this one, having been a big fan of its much more time-consuming and involved predecessor. After having sunk over 250 hours into this game though, I can honestly say it offers one of the best all-around RTS experiences you can get.

												For those who haven't played any games in this series, I suggest giving this one a miss and purchasing either Supreme Commander or SC: Forged Alliance instead. SC2 looks nicer and runs marginally better, but it's been simplified to appeal to people who don't usually play RTS games and boy does it show; the unit list has been cut down by two thirds (that doesn't stop some of the units being nearly useless); the in-game economy has been dumbed down so that it's impossible to stall; the maps and scale of the game in general have been cut back; the story is boring, as are the characters and it's also way too easy to complete.As I said: Stick with the previous games. People can talk up this one all they like - it turned out to be the one that ultimately killed the series.

number of helpful: 11 of 21 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												TL;DR: I'll put the tldr segment first because of the way they format the text:Supreme Commander 2 is a basic RTS that did not hold on to what it had in the first two games of the franchise. If you have not played the first games and are just looking for a nice looking RTS, then this is your game.I have played Supreme Commander since the original was released back in 2007, I loved that game and it brought many new features to the RTS scene that have now become pretty much standard (ex: “strategic zoom”). After the pretty much utter failure of Forged Alliance, I was pretty surprised to see a sequel to a game whose first installment was pretty good, but had lost grasp on its fans by making a spin off and releasing it as a full game at full price when it really should have been an expansion or DLC. The First two games: Supreme Commander and Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, were both produced by THQ, developed by Gas Powered Games and to quote from the boxes “An Arts From [designed by] Christ Taylor”. These games had many mechanics that separated from other RTSs that were out that the time. The games had a focus on large unit management (I’m talking 1000+ units, none of that 200 max unit stuff you see in other games) to dominate the battlefield, players also had to use the terrain to their advantage to flank their enemies. The resource management system that was in place in the first titles was also very different from other games at the time. Instead of having a set amount of resource in your position and you’re only able to build units with that set amount (if that makes any sense), SC and SCFA both had a resource rate system. This system would allow you to build as many units as you wanted, just production would slow down if you did not have a high enough rates of resources coming in, creating some pretty interesting situations when you realize that one of you Mass Extractors had been removed and you wonder why you’re not building as fast. Units in the first two games were handled by a tier system. When you could afford to spend some time and had some extra resource coming in you could choose to upgrade up to two higher (because you start on tier one) tiers unlocking new units and engineers to build. When you obtain enough tier three engineers (for sake of practicality) you could build some pretty power game ender units called Experimental Units. These beasts included things such as a mobile factory that could build almost anything almost instantly and was pretty much indestructible, to gigantic humanoid robots that would shoot laser beams from their eyes. You could also build a unit called a Support Command Units, which were smaller less functional versions of the main Armored Command Units (which is what you play as), pretty much they make great suicidal units. Now enough about the first to games in the franchise, let’s talk about Supreme Commander 2 (the third game of the series). You may be wondering why I spent all that time talking about the first games in the series; well it’s because they changed all that (well most of it). Publication of Supreme Commander 2 was transferred over to Square Enix, but was still developed by Gas Powered Games. The seconded game had more of a focus on small group combat rather than large scale unit combat like in the first game. The map design was also drastically different with even more of a requirement on terrain use. This wasn’t really a bad thing; the new maps were interesting and helped to balance the support between each kind of unit (land, air, sea). However one of the biggest flaws with in the game was with the units. They scrapped the tier system that was present in the first game for tech tree system. Gone are the days were you could build cheap factories that would pump out meat shields and cheap scouts. With this new tree system the placed in a resource, research points, along with the original two, Mass, and Energy. These points could be farmed or gained just from passing time, and then spent in the tree. Now some of these upgrades are pretty interesting, you can detach the control module of the AUC to make a quick escape and then make a bad♥♥♥♥♥comeback; but still the heavy focus on the system felt to simplify what made the first games unique and challenging; now all your factories have access two those high power units, and you no longer have to micromanage them. But by far the worst change that they made was to the resource system. They went from an “interest” based income system as I described before, to the standard “bank” system that is present in other RTSs such as Star Craft. This hurt the game, slowing the pacing down from all out action which made the first game amazing fun, to a waiting game to see who can farm the most and get Experimental Units first. In the end Supreme Commander 2 is a decent strategy game, but that’s all it is. GPG did not stick to what made the first two games so different, high pacing action with ridiculous unit counts and lots of explosions. The maps are interesting enough to keep games exciting for the first few rounds, and the visuals are fantastic even for a three year old game. However I still can’t help but feel hurt that this cult favorite that really was the benchmark for RTSs (both visually and mechanically) at the time it was released has been watered down to please a wider demographic. Also I feel that I should note that it was released a few weeks before Star Craft 2 so that didn’t help with sales. In all I would recommend the first two games over this one: Supreme Commander, and Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, if you want a unique RTS experience and don’t already own them. If you want a beautiful RTS with unique units but really basic mechanics then go right ahead and pick up Supreme Commander 2.

												Supreme commander 2, is my personal favorite warfare based game. I personal enjoy playing this approximently everyday. I have my Father, my friends, "Sameer, Justin, Will" that play this same game. On some days we have a all out war FFA AKA Free For All match. For the last couple of weeks I have been way out into this game just trying to finish the campaign again. Sense I just got the game on my new HP computer I also saw the infinite war battle making one of my favorite games into a better all out survival warfare. If you are reading this review and are thinking about buying this game on Steam. I think you should think that again, and say "Well lets go get that credit card!" Supreme commander involves complex thinking and complex options to over defeat your enemies. You need to choose wisely with your research and you mass production in the maps format. Supreme commander 2 is cheap for it great graphics, and it's great performance. I got this game 2 years or so ago when it was about 50$. And personally do you see me conplaining about this game being boring? Well if I am happy then you should be Happy.                                            -TaylorTdude :)

content:
Posted: October 7, 2015
												Big improvement over the first Supreme Commander. While it was "dumbed down", it really helped the game as a whole. They streamlined it, made the game a lot more enjoyable to actually play in the early phases AND the late game stages, as opposed to SC1, where you'd just spam mindlessly and try to pump out a T4 unit as fast as possible.I understand some people don't like the change, I don't blame them, but overall this was a good thing for the series and helped newer people get introduced to the world of Supreme Commander and therefore drew more attention to the original and to me, that's never a bad thing. I recommend giving this game a go.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												I have thoroughly enjoyed this game ever since i discovered ity on the console the battles have good length and build up time and you can actually use more in depth strategy than in other games or you can still be simple and send a giant mega army to attack the opposition. It also has a pretty good collection of mods which you have to find on your own unfortunately, and to play with others online you have to have all the same mods or just play with the base game. With the game-play itself the only issue i have is how the bots tend to rush nukes, and then just stop attacking with anything else. there are occasional unit pathing issues but they mostly self correct after a moment of trying to go where they cant. overall a great game with a good campaign as well.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												There are so many differences between Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance and Supreme Commander 2 that they should be treated as two separate RTS games. The "tactical view" of the battlefield is still a main feature, but now you have to zoom out really far to see the unit icons. Unless you zoom really close to the units, it is hard to tell immediately what the units are. The campaign story was weaker than the original, but on the bright side, the missions themselves put a lot more pressure on the player. For more of the major differences, Wikipedia has a good article.After playing Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, I was disappointed by Supreme Commander 2, mainly due to the simplified unit mix and play style. But when considered as a standalone title, this is still a decent RTS game. I'll stick with Forged Alliance, though.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												Just bought this game in the last Christmas sale for R$ 5, and it is an amazing game for the price. Max unit count is really high (500), resources are infinite in quantity yet limited by extraction rate, and the main focus of the game is on the battles. Some units are specialized against others, there are many possibilities like nukes, air strikes, air drops, artillery across the map, etc. I would not pay much more for this title if it weren't on sale, but it is a decent and complete RTS option to play with friends. Definitely recommended.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2012
												Quite possibly the only RTS to make "macro-management" a required skill, Supreme Commander 2 stands out from all other RTSs by having an interface that HELPS you with all your tasks, instead of artificially inhibiting you.  Being able to infinitely zoom in and out combined with a 500 unit cap (1 unit = 1 pop) makes Supreme Commander 2 the ultimate of large scale battles.Be sure you have at least a dual core, preferably running at least at 3.8GHZ to handle the sim speeds demanded by the game when fighting against 3+ AIs with friends.

Max unit count is really high (500), resources are infinite in quantity yet limited by extraction rate, and the main focus of the game is on the battles. Some units are specialized against others, there are many possibilities like nukes, air strikes, air drops, artillery across the map, etc. I would not pay much more for this title if it weren't on sale, but it is a decent and complete RTS option to play with friends. Definitely recommended.
