content:
Posted: September 22, 2013
												90 out of 100It's a pretty good game, with several improvements over the original. For one, I definatly like the strategic view where you can organize units into groups. Supreme Commander 2 has a much better campaign and some well-designed skirmish maps. Another key improvement is the differences in the factions. In Supreme Commander the factions were basically the same and the only difference was the appearence of the units. Supreme Commander 2 has signifigantly incresed the depth and strategy of the game. There are a few downsides though. To start there's the desreased unit cap. In the orignal Supreme Commander you could have 1000 units on the field at once, whereas now you can only have 500. Also, some of the units have lost a lot of their original power. Take the fatboy for example, in supreme commander it was an amphibious mobile factory with a shield and immense firepower. Now it's just a large tank.Overall I'd say buy Supreme Commander first and play for a while, then buy this so you can enjoy the improvemets more and have better understanding of the campaign.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Now, before I explain why I don't reccommend this, let me establish that this is, indeed, a VERY fun game. Its just dissappointing, compared to the previous SupCom games. My biggest issue, is how useless shields are. They cover next to nothing, in SupCom:FA, you could cover your entire base with 3 or 4 heavy shield generators. Now, in a DLC, you can get an experimental shield generator, but that's the DLC, and Im not talking about the DLC, Im talking about the game. Another issue I have with this, is the border markers, PDs range, shields range, etc. Its a thick ring, that doesnt give you a very precise-feeling measurement. I much prefer Supreme Commander's thin ring, it feels so much better. Also, they obliterated some of my favorite experimentals, namely the FatBoy. That thing was a beast, heavy shield gen, long range cannons, unit production capabilities. Now its just a big bloody tank. I love this game. But I would advise against buying it, go and buy the fist Supreme Commander, or Forged Alliance.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												An accesible and lightweight evolution of the original Supreme Commander (and Total Annihilation before it) that shines in online co-op multiplayer vs. AI. Each of the three factions feels unique enough to encourage different tactics and long-term strategies. AI can be configured with pre-existing difficulty and behavioral profiles or customized to make it laughably incompetent or viciously productive. Both players and AI can be configured in any combination of teams, with or without ability to break alliances during gameplay.Jeremy Soule's soundtrack is grand and sweeping. It does a fine job underscoring the tension of base building and the escalating arms race just as well as it punctuates the shrapnel-filled battles.Sure, more maps would be welcome, but luckily there are a few well-balanced layouts that offer tremendous replayability.My recommendation: Buy it for yourself and 3 friends when it's on sale, skip the single-player campaigns, and go right for co-op multiplayer vs. a few AIs.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												The first game was Supreme Commander, then came Supreme Commande : Forged Alliance, then this.Sadly it doesn't live up to the series.  The whole game feels like a cutdown version of the earlier games, like if someone had to remake Supreme Commander with only a fraction of the budget.The graphics are worse than the earlier games.  The FMV's are worse quality than the earlier games.The game balance is poor and air units are overpowered. The storyline for the singleplayer campaign is weak and very cheesy and every campaign opponent is just a sad predictable spam of gunship formations.  The regular units are bland and experimentals feel more like regular units.The campaign was easily completable on Hard difficulty for a novice like me, who barely scraped through Forged Alliance on Normal difficulty. Which leaves only skirmish and multiplayer, where the gameplay is far shallower and blander than the original game and you'll quickly grow bored of it.  What basically ruined this sequel is basically the same thing that ruins a lot of PC game sequels, a studio has initial success and then they set their eyes on the lucrative console market.Here's a quote from gamespy reviewing the Xbox 360 version of the first Supreme Commander."Cut out about 50% of the units, make the maps smaller and tighten up the bleeding edges to make a new strategic model and we might really have something. The pacing's right, the idea's right, but stuffing the entire PC version of Supreme Commander onto the 360 is just more than the poor machine can handle."That's pretty much what they did here.  The only thing Supreme Commaner 2 deserves credit for is that on the whole the skirmish A.I is somewhat improved over its predecessors in terms of actually amassing units and launching credible attacks.

Posted: August 14, 2015
												I loved the supreme commander series from the start, getting it in 2007 and playing it for hours on straight and loved every single bit of it, then forged alliance came out, which basicaly was the only way they could have ever mad SupCom any better. then 2 came out. remember the awesomness of exploring the map, building giant armies, and upgrading your tech to make your base better? well, they got rid of the tech system completely and made some wierd♥♥♥♥♥tech tree which will have you farming science and spam laboratories all over your base. and dont forget shields, because the only way to actually fight in this game is by spamming artillery that can fire acrossthe map, and yes you had that in SupCom 1 as well, but then it was tech 3 and took half an hour to build. now its (sort of, because of the tech tree) tech 2, and can be completed very quickly. armies are obsolete because of this, and the only strategy is spamming things. the campaign is filled with cliches, and really sucks compared to the earlier ones. i would not recommend this game, buy SupCom 1 or FA, but not this. also, DLC for more units? REALLY? THIS IS WHY FFA GOT MADE.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												Supreme Commander 2 is a nice RTS that is different from most others. The ability to produce units, artillery, experimentals, and general bases in one match makes it very different. Sure, maybe games like Company of Heros are kinda like that, but the SC series has a different vibe. I don't play SC2 often now, ever since I moved to its predecessor Forged Alliance.Forged Alliance in general, could be considered to be a better game. Better resource system, tech tiers instead of tech trees, experimentals are more expensive, but much more OP, etc etc. I would recommend getting Forged Alliance, but I would not go against getting this game. Supreme Commander 2 is a great game on its own, and its much more casual than FA, making it a good game to have some quick matches every now and then.Yes, I do recommend it, but I would recommend getting Forged Alliance instead.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												I like many others on here grew up playing Total Annihilation and later Supreme Commander then Forged Alliance which were all excelent games. The grand scale and complexity made them the pinnacle of strategy games unrivaled by any challenger. SC2 however is an embarassment to the franchise which lacks all the qualities that made the predesessors superior to every other Warcraft clone on the market. I cannot believe that Chris Taylor actually wanted to produce the watered down, simplistic, underachieving C&C clone(minus the good story and cut scenes). Let us all hope he is able to escape from Square Enix and work with a publisher that will allow him the creative freedom to masterfully craft the game that we all know he is capable of. number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2015
												Supreme Commander 2 (SC2) is much better than Supreme Commander 1 (SC1). Don't believe all the naysayers!SC1 had tons of different units, 4 tiers and huge maps. The intention behind SC1 apparently was to simulate epic battles. However, it failed at that miserably. The usual multiplayer games didn't last longer than 10 - 20 minutes and ended at tier 1 or tier 2 at most. So you weren't able to use most of the units anyway. No epic battles of several hours (if players played seriously).SC2 doesn't try to simulate epic battles. SC2 is a very quick game. 1on1 games usually take about 10 minutes. Everything in the game is streamlined for quick games and it never gets boring. The game just makes a lot more sense. Unlike SC1, it doesn't try to be something which it isn't. If you want longer games, play 3vs3 games which can take about 30 minutes.Cons:- The online community is practically non-existent. The game is very old after all and most players who play it don't host public games. RTS games in general aren't the most popular games.Pros:+ The game isn't expensive. Ask a few friends who like RTS games and play with or against them! IMO, the game is worth its current price of 13€ just for its skirmish mode against AI. There is also a single player campaign for all three factions.+ There are not tons of different units. Too many units make a RTS too complicated without providing a real benefit. You don't need tons of different units to have a strategic game. Too many types of units just make the game bloated and make it difficult for new players.+ The size of the maps is just right. No boring wandering around in slow moting in huge maps.+ The ACU or an engineer can build all buildings. No need to distinguish between T1, T2 and T3 engineers. Better buildings and units are unlocked via the research system. Different tiers of engineers would just have been annoying without providing any strategical depth.+ Stability. Unlike SC1, SC2 never has crashed on my PC.+ Easy to pick up, difficult to master. That's what a RTS game should be like. There is a lot of depth in the game, e.g. knowing how to counter which strategy of the enemy.+ The factions play very differently. Every faction has its own cool things and the balance seems to be very good.+ Beforehand I was sceptical when I heard that the mass and energy isn't reduced per second when constructing but you have to pay the full amout of mass and energy for buildings and units. In fact it works perfectly. Nothing to miss about the old economy system of SC1 (or Total Annihilation).+ It is not possible to build a turtle base which withstands everything. Allowing too heavy turtling would only lenghten the game without making it more interesting. In SC2 attacking is the best defense.+ There is a lot of tension in the game. You always have something to do. There is no time for breaks. Fortunately, a game is short enough to be able to relax *after* the game ;)Conclusion: SC2 is the result of streamlining SC1. It's not a trivial game like some people may try to make you believe. IMO, the right things were simplified but the developers never oversimplified anything.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2016
												Don't buy this game. If you want a good game buy Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, its a much better game. Supreme Commander 2 or 'Soup Commander' as I like to call it is terrible. I played this game for 25.5hrs (based on steams account not strait of course) I have never gone back to it and have since uninstalled it, on the other hind I still play Forged Alliance with and without mods.Forged Alliance has deep characters, plot and with battles covering huge stretchs of land, the largest of these being 81kmx81km. Soup Commander dumbs now and shrinks everything plot, characters and the battlefield.In Forged Alliance, there are three factions fighting for galactic dominance. First the UEF professional soldiers of a corrupt government. Second Aeon have advanced technology while trying to spread their beliefs at the barrel of a gun. Third the Cybran Nation a splinterd orgainization lead primarily by a 1000 your old scientist who is trying free those enslaved by the UEF while having inferior numbers.Then there is the Soup Commander (this game here your looking at). It has three factions fighting for planetary dominance. First the UEF power tripping football players who violate rules like it a requirement of day to day life. Second Aeon religious idiots fighting against none Aeon society as it is oppressive all while infighting. Third the Cybran Nation a megalomaniac mad sicentist lead terrorist group that fights amongst its self as much as it does others.As you can see they don't even seem related, aside from the names of the faction and game. so Again if you want a good game buy Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance don't get this one.DO NOT BUY THIS GAME

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												I can only recommend this game if its almost literally "Baby's First RTS"Functionally its fairly smooth, tech progresses at a fairly easy to undersand rate and resources are very easy to graspIf this had any other title, my only gripe would be that its a somewhat shallow strategy game split between two major recurring problems. 1) matches degrade into a race to nuclear munitions or 2) If nukes are switched off, battles become a competition typically of who brought more units (and in most cases, who is spamming experimentals)However, since this game does bare the name of a sequel to Supreme commander 1 and Forged alliance, its going to get a major thumbs down from me. To put things simply, it feels desperate. Over 3/4ths of the units vanished between forged alliance and 2 it seems, everything feels either too squishy or too beefy with very little in between. The fact that I can park 10 navy cruisers off the enemy base within 5 minutes of the match starting (the 'youre not allowed to enjoy the game' tactic) and shut down the game before it can start..? The fact that nuclear weapons are relatively cheap and quick to build, often removing further the concept of strategy. I suppose what it comes down to is; Of the units left in the game, do all of them feel absolutely necissary? Do all of them have a very clear use that cant be easily covered by another. My answer is no, any match can be won through spamming pretty much any one unit whether that be tanks, artillery, gunships, navy, nuclear missilesWhatever your fancy, its been watered down so much you might as well slap a dasani label on it. Addendum : I recommend this if youre looking for an introduction into RTS, things arent so crazy fast as starcraft but not as slow as some others. Expansion moves with the player even with its problems. If youre more confident in your ability however, Skip this. Dont even consider it an option. Go pick up Forged Alliance and have hours of fun ducking and dodging, surgically decapitating the enemy forces, and striking the final decisive blow.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												As a player of Supcom and Forged Alliance I found Supcom 2 was rather lacking in content, as a point of fact I figured, seeing as it was a continuation of the originals, that jumping into a skirmish rather than learning the controls would be fun, I was wrong. There is no strategy involved, simply throwing masses of troops seems to work fine. The look of the game, both graphically and from my brief inspection of the tutorial, seems very similar to some of Westwoods Command and Conquer games. Were I a new player to the series I'd most likely assume it was a prequel to the originals with the way it looked.I still had fun though, regardless of my initial shock, and I felt as though it had been made with an older feel in mind.All in all I was dissapointed with what I got out of this game. Was it good? No. Were it part of a different series of games I may have said differently but this is a poor excuse for a SupCom game. I do expect I'll play the game more but will no doubt return to the orignal games after completing the  campaign.Pro's:Some of the unit names are clear puns which made me chuckleThe old SupCom/FA maps made an appearanceSomewhat corny and old school feelCon's:For SupCom players; expect lower graphics than the originalsSeems untempered and in need of tweaksLack of strategy value, throw units at the enemy and wear them into the dirt

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												After 700 hours playing this game I thought it might be time to rate it !When Supreme Commander Forged Alliance was released I was a big fan and used to play a lot with friends. We all loved the macro-management and these huge playgrounds to fight each other.Some people say Supreme Commander 2 is not a SC anymore. I would say it is, just a much more balanced version ! Power of experimentals were reduced, making it possible to fight an experimental with classic units. Also, maps are smaller, this is not a con ! It makes the game more "rush-friendly" to push people not to turtle every game until you get an experimental to leave your base.Apart from that, graphics are great, music is great, camera is very good with rotation mode when you want to watch at your badass units annihilating the enemy base, oh yeah and the DLC 'Infinite War Battle Pack" adds very interesting buildings and units that greatly improve the different ways you can ply !Go for it ! It's a great strategy game.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												What to say about this game.  First visually it looks great, even several years after the release it looks great.  Gameplay wise its in shambles.  User interface and function is terrible.  Im not an expert at the so called 4x strategy games, part of this issue comes from really poorly designed user interfaces.  Instead of providing options to manage base building on the fly you are required to bounce back and forth with your units.  Couple that with an AI that can do that on the fly, makes this very frustrating.  Unit building is slow and you cant tell if something is building or not, the contruction should be individual to each building unit and not ordered by unit, so it makes unit construction slow and painful since most times when i should be seeing a massive group of units waiting for me to select, instead all i see is one and the next one is in a queue waiting because the unit from a different pool is currently be produced and this is on top of a possitive resource system with excess  resources waiting.  This is on top of the typical AI crap that is in every game, the AI will always have available the exact unit to counter my units and have almost immediate access to replacement units.  The single player game is a choir after the first two missions because of this.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												Think of an RTS as a rhythm game. It's all about finding a decent rhythm in unit production, to research, to micro and macro with your entire army. You must maintain your rhythm while also disrupting your opponent's. I bought this game during the Winter sale for $3.24. This game isn't even worth THAT.Here's where this game's problem comes in: this game makes no ♥♥♥♥ing sense. The tutorial was written by ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ seven year olds who don't the understand the basic concept of what makes an RTS an RTS. The game's rhythm is all place, it feels like Beethoven did a line of cocaine on his piano and then bashed his face on the piano keys. If my friends have to tell me to not play the Tutorial and just experience the mechanics on their own to like this game, only for me to bash my keyboard in blind fury at the stupidity of the mechanics, things aren't boding well.This is coming from a person who plays RTS games all the time. I have over 6000 hours on games like Total Annihilation Kingdoms (June 25, 1999), War of the Ring (November 4 2003), StarCraft (March 31, 1998) and StarCraft 2 (July 27, 2010) and WarCraft 3 (July 3, 2002). Mind you, StarCraft 2 came out THE SAME YEAR as this game. It took me FOUR MINUTES to understand the components of StarCraft 1 and how to play it, and even less time to understand StarCraft 2. I've played for almost over an hour and STILL don't understand what makes this game tick.Each and every one of the games I just spoke of above have superiority in all aspects, leagues above this game. Game feel, mechanics, art design, story, ease of accessibilty, easy to understand, and gameplay. I have not played any of the other Supreme Commander games, but from the looks of it, not only does this game♥♥♥♥♥♥on its predecessors, but on Strategy games as a whole.Do not buy this game.Refunded. I want my ♥♥♥♥ing $3.24 back. No words will be able to express exactly how♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥I am on this game. This game caused me to go on a freaking rage rant on the history of Strategy games for around two hours with my friends being forced to smile and nod.

												First off,  this isn't a bad RTS compared to some others that are available but compared to it's predecessors it's a shadow of the franchises former glory. The graphics hold up suprisingly well and it's the alpha and the omega of what an RTS should be.  Seriously,  if you're a fan of 4x RTS (like Sins of a Solar Empire)  then you should really have it in your library.  This game is good if you prefer RTS's on a smaller scale but after playing the predecessors it feels smaller and therefore watered down to me.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2015
												Supreme Commander 2 is the "hit" sequel to the last game, Supreme Commander, and yet you would never know this due to the fact that they changed every single thing, pretty much leaving only superficial elements, like faction emblems.  They've gutted every single unit, every character, every part of the story, and the maps. Now, you're probably wondering "isn't this good? I thought sequels were supposed to change stuff?" You'd be right, but unfortunately, no change was for the better in this game. I can go on all day about the failings of this game, but to be quick about it I'll run down some bulletpoints. This review has been a long time coming, and I figured that now would be the best opportunity to do it, considering my most recent run of the game.-the gameplay has been made much simpler, which hurts it in the long run, because the developers forgot to compensate for this, and so the singleplayer is extremely easy, and multiplayer (if you can even find a match on the dead servers) is Starcraft 2-tier. Just like Blizzard's poor RTS sequels, all you do is just mass units and slam them against the opposition, without ever worrying about economy or defending multiple fronts. The original Sup Com may have had hints of this, but there was pure unit variety to make up for it, which meant strategies were opened up. With Sup Com 2, you just have basic units that you upgrade, almost like it's an RPG or something. -the upgrade system, which is supposed to be how you make your units better, is lazy and poorly implemented. It locks your entire army behind arbitrary walls and you have to upgrade before your'e allowed access to them. The upgrades don't do much to improve their survivability, as even a whole armada of tanks will fall to a small wall of defenses. Plus, the way you upgrade them (with research stations) is a no-thought process in itself, as you can just throw down 20 of them and instantly get all upgrades in no time at all. You don't even suffer an economic downturn since they cost so little. I give Starcraft some credit, at least locking units behind requirements made sense, and upgrading was a process that took time, but was worth it. It's not even worth mentioning how badly it cripples your ability to switch to another form of unit, be it land, sea or air. If you didn't waste your time and economy unlocking everything on land, and you suddenly need sea units, you're out of luck. -pathing and unit AI took a major turn for the worst, as your army will continually fumble over itself trying to go into even open corriors. Sometimes your units will prioritize looking at flowers while your base is burning half-way across the map. This is why I don't recommend attack+moving, ever. -graphically the game looks like burnt meatloaf that someone tried to save by slathering it with ketchup. The colors are too bright and don't mesh well into the environments, and the units put the "ugh" in ugly.  If you dont like it, too bad. Unit variety went out the window, so you'll be staring at the same ugly tanks and anorexic mechs on the same poorly rendered maps. -The maps are also unreliably stupid. Some are just poorly balanced, or not even balanced at all. Half are just ripped from the campaign, so you can tell there's laziness in the fact that some guys will get superior footholds. -Now for the story. Who here cares for story in an RTS, right? Well, I kinda did. I didn't obsess over it, but the original Sup Com had charm in its story. Sup Com 2 took notes from Starcraft 2 and had it be about some generic loner who has issues. For Jim, he had lady issues. For Dominic, he had family issues. Specifically some half-handed plot about fantastical racism. Also, there were subplots about terrorists and Dr. Brackman's extended family, but it reads more like fanfiction from people who just read Ayn Rand. William Gauge was a fun guy, but couldn't save the story. Oh, and some super weapon plot happpens later, but I doubt you'll care-lastly, the game was very poorly made, in terms of software. Even on the lowest settings, some units like illuminate experimentals will drag my framerate to a complete stop, and other things will cause the game to crash horribly. The original Sup Com didn't run perfect, but it ran consistent.  It didn't make me avoid using units due to fear of framerate drops. Overall, avoid this game, as it doesn't deserve to be called a sequel to one of the finest RTS's I've ever played. And don't be fooled by my 30+ hours played. That was me trying to justify the money I spent on the game, to avoid buyer's remorse. If you want to see how much time I put into a game I enjoy, take a look at how much I spent on the prequels to this stinker.

												Cash grab product due to success of SCFA.- bad design choices such as:Terrain seems to have been developed by one team and unit models by another and then smashed together for release.No distinction between models, everything seems the same with some mix, except experimentals ofc.The quality of art is just shoddy.- short campaign with sub par voice acting (or rather, the script is cringeworthy).- massively inferior unit management (no building blueprints, cant build if you have more than 1 engi selected, and plethora of UI inferiorities to the first game).- small maps, small unit caps (thx consoles)....I could go on and on, but this game does not warrant me to give a♥♥♥♥♥♥I could not find a positive aspect to this game.Everything from the main menu to the end of campaign just reeks of low budget to maximise quarterly revenue during steam sale and whatnot.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												SC2 embodies the sprirt of the RTS genre. The multidimensional, macroscopic wars that can be waged offer an impressive approach to strategy as a video game dynamic. The sheer scale of some of the units in this game are both humbling and awe-inspiring to any player willing to consider what some of these steel behemoths would look like in real life. Also, there are a number of well made mods that add tons of new content and gameplay mechanics to SC2. I would recommend these to anyone that is getting bored with the vanilla version of the game.

												I am glad I waited until this game was on sale for a few bucks.It is definitely not even close to the value of previous Supreme Commander games.  It plays more like a fast paced MOBA or Mario type game where speed is more important than strategy.  There is a great deal of scripting which sometimes includes your own units, when they are controlled by a script and you are helpless and just have to watch and scramble your remaining units.It is way dumbed down from previous versions, and looks like it was made to appeal to a completely different crowd.I truly loved the first two games of this series, but I can't bring my self to play this beyond the first level.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2016
												Okay...My opinion regarding SupCom2 is a little...neutral. The game itself is okay and adds an interesting twist to the SupCom universe. However, it isn't the TRUE successor to the original SupCom game.For one, the resource system. It just seems...eh. It changed from the positive/negative income and moved to building/unit pricing where you need X amount of resources to buy Y. Doesn't exactly endear me.Another point is the research tree and research points. Why?! I was perfectly okay with going through three techs. T1, T2, T3. Simple. Easy to understand. But now, I've been given a third resource. I'm a casual gamer, I don't do competitive stuff very often. Rant at me if you wish, but getting a third resource was a pain in the carping♥♥♥♥♥ When I tried to move to focus on one thing, something else suffers. Honestly, I would forget about research and then half way through the match, remember I can upgrade my stuff. So, meh. Not enthused.I do have a pet peeve. Why can't I order engineers to assist in building something? In SupCom original, build time could be cut down if you assigned an engineer to work on it, of course at the cost of using more resources. But it's gone now. I'm not pleased by the lack of that mechanic, but I can live with it. I guess...Now, I HAVE to bring up the naming. Seriously, take a moment and look at the Aeon Illuminate unit names. The 'Weedoboth' fighter/bomber? The 'Sooprizer' Experimental Gunship? The 'Fistoosh' Mobile Missile Launcher? I'm mildly amused. And I'm also questioning the alcohol content the designers possessed when they named these. That, or sleep deprivation. Or it could be they had only a week before release. I unno.One last thing. When I first played SupCom, I was blown away by this 'epic' feeling. The units and their attacks held a kind of weight to them, as if a single shot from a T3 Aeon Battleship could conceivably oneshot most structures and units. Now, these units in SupCom2 just feel dinky and unrefined, even when at maximum upgrade sometimes. Sure, it doesn't hold true to all units, but it's present in most. The build time is also shortened. When you went to build a Tech3 artillery piece on SupCom original, you EARNED it. It took an hour to build that thing, you deserve it and its firepower. In SupCom2, you have TWENTY heavy artys, maybe more. You can spam them for days and don't get me started on the nukes. I'm not even gonna step in that territory of rant. I've done enough for tonight.Long story short, if you want a sequel to SupCom original, go get Forged Alliance.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27
												As far as real time strategy games go, you really cannot do much better than supreme commander 2.Yes, square enix is basically gone.  Yes, the story line is more or less just there to say "this game has a story."  And yes, this game is old.But it more than makes up for it with the massive armies you can command (1000 unit count, but realistically the max is 700 individual units since you need a little space for structures... like mass extractors and powerplants).  It has just the right amount of variety of units for each faction.  Truely exotic buildings, like a structure that can instantly teleport a massive army of small units or say 50 expeariemntals (one expeariemntal is worth 50-100 normal units... just imagine what that would do to a base... or a commander's unit) in to the very center of the enemies main base, or a artically cannon that shoots smaller units instead of projectiles, or a giant magnet/meatgrinder that sucks and destroys 100s of smaller units before it has to cooldown.Exotic weapons such as a kraken submarine, flying aircraft factory, and a literal flying saucer.You can have as many as 10 commanders in one game, 5 per side.  Massive maps.  And ways to cheat resource limits, like energy to mass converters - which consume massive amounts of energy and need to be manually activated each time you use them - can provide you enough mass (resource) to make the next batch of elite units.Giant robots.  Nukes.  Floating baby belle cheese rolls of death.  Artillary arrays.  Armadas.  Armies.  More nukes.   Walking battleships.  Sky-fleets.  Giant flying brains.Need I go on?

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Was great, superior to the first game even, until they patched it to play just like the first game (in terms of resource managment) and thus revived all the reasons i stopped playing the original title. Do not recommend.(EDIT: someone axed a question and steam wont let me type a reply over 1000 characters.)answer to question about what specifically was changed: to anyone who hasn't played the original it wouldn't really make any additional sense with context. but 'ere we go!the original game suffered from a lot of cons: slow down, extremely lengthy build queues, poor balance between factions, the necessity of having pre-created construction blueprints for base building, to name a few. the most poignant of all, however, was the resource management system this RTS employed. effectively you could queue up ANYTHING regardless of actual resource reserves or resource income rate. buildings, units, upgrades, all of it would simply go into the queue as you picked them. in most RTS games, if you can't afford something, you had to wait until you COULD to produce it. supreme commander 1 said "nuts to something easy and efficient such as that!" and decided that to compensate for letting you always be able to construct anything it would merely extend the production time. so now, a tier 1 tank that took 20 seconds to create with adequate resources became a tier 1 tank that takes 3 minutes to create as resources trickle in and are equally distributed amongst all queued tasks that you do not pause. this could get GROSSLY out of hand if you were not keeping up with mass and energy generation. experimentals that took 6 minutes to construct were taking 30 minutes. ain't NOBODY but a guy i knew named Andrew had time fo dat. along comes supreme commander 2 and SUDDENLY we had a resource management system that made SENSE! (we also had other marked improvements across the board from performance to simplications of unneccessarrilly complicated game mechanics, which some people, namely the aforementioned Andrew did not enjoy). The system had been changed so that you could queue up whatever you wanted but construction/progess would NOT begin until you had the total necessary resources to complete the item in the default build time. effectively the game was working like every other RTS in existence because you don't revolutionize the wheel by making it into a hexagon. along came a patch for SC2 that changed the resource management system into a carbon copy of the system from SC1. this made the game VIRTUALLY unplayable to me. i went from being able to beat the entire game to being unable to launch the game from steam because i couldn't stand that system after having been spoiled by the infinitely superior system the game launched with. the game lost ALL appeal and in an instant became unplayably boring and frustrating. They didn't even make it an OPTION. (did they? i doubt it.)

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2014
												A really fun RTS. The graphics are good but the most noticeable thing about the game are the effects. The flash of weapons firing, targets being hit, things exploding, it all looks really good and this game has some great presentation value. I'm the SUPREME COMMANDER zOMG! A lot of RTS games try to add new things and end up increasing micromanagement big time. I took two micromanagement economics classes in college, I don't need more of it lol. A lot of RTS games just feel like work instead of enjoying a game. This game gives you a way to build armies and to research upgrades and it is not overly detailed with who-cares-what-else. It is easy to get into with a quick and to the point how-to tutorial. Why can't all rts games be this intuitive? Why do they have to add layers upon layers upon layers of micromanagement and boring tedious details? Because the people who make them and play them are pretentious d-bags, that's why. I would play this over pretentious CIV games any ♥♥♥♥ing day.Although not complicated, it is still a challenge. That's the one problem I've found so far and it sucks: very uneven difficulty spikes. Missions 1-3 out of 5 in the first campaign? Whatever, it was no problem. Mission 4 in the first campaign? It was ♥♥♥♥ing stupidly hard. I got it on my third try when I realized you need to do it a specific way which is one of my biggest pet peeves with games: lack of player freedom. You can't build additional money generators in this mission so you do not have a lot of resources coming in so you have to plan it precisely. I figured out that you have to build a ton of ground/air defense towers and keep engineers repairing them and replacing them as needed. Have enough towers to guard the front and NW/NE sides and a bunch of fighter planes on guard and upgrade their health/dmg fully. Be working up to building the walking juggernaut things as quickly as you can while upgrading ground forces health/dmg fully. Keep pumping out fighter planes from two air factorys. After all this, I sent out two juggernauts with 40 air fighter support planes and blasted everything down finally. God, damn.I suppose in closing I can say this is a decent RTS game but really it just makes me want to reinstall Starcraft 2.6.5/10

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												This game stinks compared to supreme command 1 and forged alliance. They took everything that made those two unique to the rts genre and threw it out the window. I don't even get how supcom2 is supposed to work.First all the resources became like static. Gone is the balance of energy and metals in vs spent. You can't upgrade your collectors anymore. So basically each level you are completely limited on resources. Then they severly limited the number of units you can build. All the maps are smaller. So you end up just building the biggest units you can. And then they drastically reduced the number of units. No more countering units and build specific strike groups of mixed types. And now units have upgrades instead of different level bases. So you just spam upgrades, build as much research facilities as you can and then max everything. All strategic depth, rushing vs building, what to build, what stuff to use, it's all gone.I didn't even finish it cus it's so bland. And even if you didn't play supcom1, it's still a very dull rts game. Just go get supcom1, please. Don't waste your time here.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Babies first RTS plain and simple. Absolutely horrific economy (seriously it's one of the worst I've ever seen it's so bad you never have any resources unless you convert energy into mass) Terrible unit balancing terrible UI. The game is generally♥♥♥♥♥♥so why do I find myself enjoying it? Oh that's right. Veterans of RTS want to introduce new friends into the RTS genre to have more people to play with. But if you're not already a fan of RTS type games being thrown into SCFA (Supreme Commander Forged Alliance) Is overwhelming and you'll likely uninstall the game shortly after out of frustration. So anyone who by default does not have the brain injury required to enjoy RTS games should buy this one first. SC2 is babys first RTS which I said earlier. It's used to get new RTS players into the scene because if you stuck them into a real RTS they would fall down on their face and cry. TL:DR If you like RTS games go buy Supreme Commander Forged Alliance. If you want a friend/girlfriend/boyfriend to get INTO rts games then buy them this play it with them until they're good then buy them SCFA so you never have to play this disgusting excuse for a SC game ever again.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												If you're a fan of the first supreme commander than take note, this game:- Has less tactical elements and requires less thinking.- Has shorter, more fast paced games with less focus on strategy.- Is much easier to learn and play.- Run out of things to do faster with only three factions and a relativly small arsenal.Otherwise by all means its a great game, alot of patches and the DLC (which i heavily recommend if you want to play alot) have made it more balanced than its xbox version. If you plan on playing online have some friends because finding random online players borders on impossible. Its a good bit of fun, but not really for the more serious RPG players. The campaign is not bad at all and fighting AI can be a good way to kill time. Considering its low price and low technical requirements, by all means buy it if your looking for a cool RPG!

content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												Supcom 2 is a rather fantastic RTS game and a nice continuation of the series. While I'm not too keen on the story, I know the mechanics and units make the game on par with RTS games like Command and Conquer. The experimental are a good idea implemented well. I see some people don't enjoy it, but I'll never find out why. It's very well polished and the balance is pretty good. It's difficult for me to pick a unit that's too good. While I can think of a few that're pretty bad, one of the Aeon units in particular, that mostly comes from the overspecialization of Aeon units in particular. Either way, worth it.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Definitely no.I simply love SC1 (and the expansion). I liked the serious atmosphere, the almost constant battle between resource generation and consumption, the demanding time, resources e careful planning in order to build a decent base with proper defenses. Anyway, SC1 is cool, SC2....eee....no.SC2 have its merits. The stories and more elaborate dialogues is a good thing but don't save the game. Unfortunately, good RTS games aren't make eith just good stories and dialogues. Everything that make SC1 an awesome game were removed from SC2:1 - Serious look and atmosphere - SC2 look like some kind of cartoon with bright colors from some kindergarten.2 - Resources - its easy to get and generate resources. No more paying attention or planning the construction of base or experimental units.3 - Building base - in SC1 we need to overlap shields (paying attention to energy consumption) and hope they would hold long enought while your defense structures and units take care of the enemey. In SC2, just one shield will do for everything.4 - Tactics - why bother thinking on how you will get to your enemy? Just spam anything from your factories and make them move straight for the enemy base. Pincer attacks? Too much trouble. Coordinated sea, land and air attack? Even more trouble. Artillery fire? It's boring.Anyway, the devs maybe were drunk, in a bad mood or just left their kids in charge, i don't know. But they just took everything that make SC1 an remarkable game and throw them in the trash. And painted everything with neon paint....too childish.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												An okay standalone game, and pretty cool really. (Voice acting and writing is godawful though)A great way to convert console gamers, but as a sequel to the beloved Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, this really does disappoint.People say that this game was dumbed down and ruined by consolification. Not quite true, as while it's undoubtedly dumbed down, Supreme Commander also got a console release (can't vouch for Forged Alliance though). I think it's a Square Enix publisher issue. For example, the unit cap was considerable larger in older games, and while it's still large by default, it doesn't live up to the old standard. However, and I think this may be a sign that the devs KNEW this game was worse, you can change your unit cap in a .prefs file in your "Appdata\Local\Gas Powered Games\Supreme Commander 2\" folder. (Only tested up to 1000.) You can also activate the ETA timer in there (another removed feature), so that when you hold SHIFT to queue, you can see a (normally incorrect) ETA. I don't really understand. It's like they added it, but it was turned off, lowered or removed at the last minute, and I can't imagine that's the devs. It's sad to see SupCom die, really, and this game can be quite a bit of fun with friends, but the campaign is awful too. The gameplay is dumbed down (but you knew that already), and the voice acting sounds like they were bored. If anyone played Spider-Man 2 on PS2, Xbox or Gamecube (but not PC - god not PC) then it's like the citizen voice acting; they sound bored as hell, and slightly underpaid and rushed. The writing is cheesy too, so I don't really know what went on there (although that trailer above really wants to push this 'awesome story').It's said for me to say I don't recommend this game; it does have it's moments; but I can't understand some of the choices made. Especially when it had such potential - well, I say that, but making games is hard, people have misfires, and while this is a big one (it killed the franchise as far as I'm aware)TL;DR: Get SC:FA if you want a really good RTS, or get Supreme Commander: Gold Edition or whatever it was called to get both 1 and FA.

												okay first off, before I say anything, I don't like this game, it made way to many mistakes, and didn't give enough content. Now to start the review, this game is great, if it weren't supreme commander, this was made to be part of the supreme commander series, and in that respect failed, the modeling was weird as well, and the gameplay was like taking all supreme commander veterans, and calling them noobs, it made the economy system so easy, all you have to do is give your acu a command and it will happen quite quickly, and way to easily.  not only that but the matches are to short, they don't offer, well, fun.  If I were to recommend this to anyone, it would be the people that want an easy RTS, and like easily made weapons of mass desruction, that just as easily fall.  I get that Square Enix had their own vision, but they didn't have the one that all of us wanted in a supreme commander game, I'm going back to forged alliance, see you on the battlefield.

Из минусов могу выделить оптимизацию, но это такой минус, который не всегда актуален, ежели у вас не совсем ведро, то на высоких сойдет, а если мшина помощнее можно и на ултрах побезумствовать. content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												Terrible AI and as cool as the Units are, they are terrible.  Planes stray off, tanks sit around while they get destroyed, worker bots are hard to keep track of.  An don't even try to shield your (Experimentals) heavy units, they only work well alone.  I felt like I should just name my commander Zap Brannagin.  "Now, like all great plans, my strategy is so simple an idiot could have devised it. On my command all ships will line up and file directly into the alien death cannons, clogging them with wreckage."The Campaign is not fun, an a little short, after beating the game I still have no idea what any of the factions are about.  Mission starts are annoyingly unproductive and lack direction.  I hate when the explosions start shaking the screen when I'm trying to lay down a row of turret defenses, and Micro-manage my units at the same time.  Trying to put down Experimental factories are a pain. (because they're so bulky)   Plus, there is no help in the dialouge, it's just annoying, I feel nothing for any of the characters.It is worth a play if you like RTS games.  Like I said, the units are cool.  I do like the skirmish maps (lots of build space) and the ability to zoom out to full map is sweet.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2014
												This one is a tricky one for many reasons. Ive seen other reviews and people say that they have played many strategy games and this one is a good one and  i agree. This game on its own is a decent strategy game, with more tactics then strategy though. The so called strategy is basic and "streamlined". It takes no real brains to play and is just a spam fest. Its just build big units send them at your enemy in waves and whoever does the best job or sucks the least wins is what it boils down to. I was excited when this game first came out being a fan of the first supreme commander and supreme commander forged alliance. If you analyze this game from its predisessors this game is a huge let down. The graphic quality is inferior to that of the first supreme commander in my opinion. There is very little unit variation which is sad because the first 2 had so many diverse units that each had their role on the battle field. The one thing in my opinion that kills this game if you are a fan of the first two games is the eco system. In my opinion that alone was a major stepback in the wrong direction. In all they took the core concepts that made the first 2 titles great, "streamlined" them and made a game for casuals  ( which is not nessessarily a bad thing).  If your a newcomer you will enjoy this game, if you have played the other two this game will have little replayabilty value after a short time.

number of helpful: 1 of 5 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
												I've tried writing a review harping on about everything in detail but I can’t do it, this will have to do.Simply don't buy this game, the graphics have gone down the drain, storytelling went the way of Hollywood Godzilla/Transformers, away from the interesting bits and focusing on the humans and their sob story. Building stuff is a drag if you don't have the exact "change" then you can't even begin construction, nothing seems to run on power ergo no way to tie up resources to choke the shields, meaning usual tactics are out of the window, this truly has become a spam and attack RTS.Everything has been changed, mostly for the worse, the experimentals all became smaller and less impressive or non-existent, they are all built by factories now and even the experimental factories can’t begin constructing the experimentals until you have exact change. I nearly cried when I saw the Fatboy enter the scene in campaign, no shields, no AA and not a factory, the size of the Fatboy has also gone down in size it doesn’t even resemble the one from Supreme Commander or FA.Simply put, if you like Supreme Commander then don’t buy this or maybe do so you’ll be able to appreciate FA even more.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												I bought this game on sale a while back because I had fun memories of Supreme Commander 1. The game feels lackluster compared to Supreme Commander 1. The building system is pretty linear and lack luster and it feels like there's a lack in unit option. In order to build better units they implemented a research system, it's a resource that generates overtime and you can increase the resource generation by building more research stations.What makes the game incredibly unfun is that it feels like you need to commit to one type of army because of the research system. If you build a land army and commit your research on it but later on you want to add an air army into the mix the air army will be incredibly weak making your overall army weaker.I bought this for the campaign. In the campaign, the naval army isn't always available to be built in most of the campaign, it's specially important for the Cybrans because their naval army has a research that allows them to walk on land and the ships are pretty overpowered compared to land units. The game only comes with 18 missions, 6 missions per race and all the missions aren't difficult.The skirmish felt much better in SC1. I enjoyed skirmishes turtling it out against hordes of insane AI armies marching in the door. What makes this less appealing is that only the UEF has a tier 2 defense, plus there aren't any walls you can build.Overall the game is best defined as meh. If your interested in checking out this RTS, you should buy Supreme Commander 2 first then buy Supreme Commander 1 and Forged Alliance so that you will feel like the gameplay was improved.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2016
												while it pains me to not recommend this game. Because while it updated the graphics and AI, Supreme Commander 2 changed many things: it changed its Economy from Supreme Commander 1 and Forged Alliances floating economy system to full payment upfront. it took away many unit types and Supreme Commander 2 was attemting to obsolete the 'clumsy' tier system with the the Research System (which i though was kind of neat to an extent), the maps are far to small and the maximum pop cap is 500 and the maximum map size being 40x40km (approx.) compared to SupCom and Forged Alliances maximum pop cap 1000 and the maximum map size is 81x81km. now i get to my final item the Experimentals because in Supreme Commander 2 they made them Dirt Cheap to build but stong enough to take out a fair bit of low tier units, but  in SupCom and Forged Alliance when you started building that Experimental  you knew  your economy could handle the strain and when it was done you felt a sense of pride when it was finished, because if you didnt have a stong enough economy just building the cheapest Experimental would break your economy.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												Awful writing. Awful characters I don't care about. Awful dialog. Okay, so, RTS games aren't 100% about the single player, and it's okay that this one has an awful campaign.I come from the background of Starcraft/Warcraft, where I probably have 500+ hours played on Starcraft 2's ladder, making it to masters league. I'm a very skilled RTS player, and I do not know how this game could ever have a competitive scene, as the tools to be a better player just do not exist with  such a lack of depth in skill.How can you expect me to play an RTS that doesn't have hotkeys to create a unit when you select that building? With such a bad UI? There's no menu options to change hotkeys that already exist, even! It was released a few months before Wings of Liberty, and you can't have this quality of production with such a huge competitor arriving on the scene in the same year.The clicks and keys are unresponive, I can never really tell if my unit "understood" that I gave them a command. The combat is slow, the units are boring, and the only distinguishing factor about this game (the command overview, zooming out to see the entire battlefield) apparently was done better by its predecessor which is now modded to be a better experience.I was excited to get an RTS game in a Humble Bundle. Especially one that has 87% positive reviews on Steam. I would not buy this game for any amount.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2011
												The battle is inevitable, the enemy is knocking at your front door with an army of hundreds of deadly machines. You check your own army, do you got enough defence turrets, resources and machines to drive them back? Your cannons start to pounder against the enemy while they advance against you, then you realize that one of your experimental robot is ready for battle. You get quick smirk on your face and counter-attack. You think you got the enemy on the run, suddenly you feel a cold chill running down your spine. You hear a sudden sound: "Strategic launch Detected".... this is what it's all about, the thrill of the game: To annhilate your enemy with as much fire power as possible.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												Two part review:Single-player:intersting but easy. Even at the higher difficulties, it can get very easy to determine the AIs tactics. Cutscenes and story aren't exactly intersting. good for getting to know the game mechanics, but thats about it.Multi-player:Loads of fun, with/without friends. everyone presents a different challenge, a new set of tactics to try to counter. and co-op vs. AI can be fun too. Good game all around. Not nessesarily great at almost anything, but not a bad game either. Would advise that you get it when it is on sale.

Posted: December 28, 2013
												8.5/10Pretty good game, seeing as how they expanded it in the direction I wanted them to from the first game. Expanded research, actually strategy instead of throwing stuff at the opponenet, and all the usual graphics and stuff that come with a new game. However, they basically halved the general map size, reducing match length, and they removed the different tier levels, which had its pros and cons. Overall, a great game following up from the first one.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												I know this game got beat up on release. To be fair, I think most of the criticisms were valid as compared to the original: smaller map scale, smaller unit count, simplified game mechanics, etc.. That being said, as a general RTS's go, this is a very fun game. You can have huge battle with hundred of robots duking it out on land, sea, and air. Just as importantly the game is very well optimized so you can field huge armies with no lag. If you love SUPCOM and TOTAL ANNIHILATION, this will scratch the itch unti PLANETARY ANNIHILATION is released.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												OK first of all I'm only recommending this game because it IS fun on it's own, but if you want a true sequel to supreme commander this is not it.  The battles are smaller and much less epic feeling than the originals, but to make up for this the units you do make are more important and custimizable through research.  I felt the story wash lacking any real charm and didn't really satify me with the ending, but multiplayer and skirmish matches are very fun indeed.  These battles "almost" bring it to the epic feeling of supreme commander originals.  All in all though, this game is very fun and is a good game to play if your bored out of mind or need to hold you over until another game come out.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Great example of what an RTS should bring to the table! The singleplayer is a little bit lacking, but the game really comes to shine in the multiplayer mode, where every game ensures epic battles, aided by the constant decision making that shows in every great RTS. Supreme Commander 2, whilst a bit rusty and ambiguous at certain points and lacking a bit of flair in the singleplayer, still provides an experience that is well worth the $13 price tag.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												This game is awesome for any RTS fan.  The scale is enormous and takes on multiple battles on seperate fronts.  It requires a lot of multitasking.  Maps are twice to four times the size of SC II, but the bigger units are pretty visible on the map.  My favorite aspect of this game is the pure awesome sight of watching your huge monstrous units walk the map; they don't just dwarf the smaller units, they make them look like ants!!  It's so much more different than other RTS games in the scale of battle alone.

												This may be a bit late, but i thought it would be wise to share my thoughts on this game, as far as Strategy games go, this is one of the largest scaled ones i've seen, giving massive battlefields, high-tech units and destructive power to everything, unleashing my inner desire to kill everything in a large area, while having a big play area to have so much fun with! Up to 8 player maps, maxed out games can end in 15min or up to 2hours long, giving a wide variety of ways to build your forces and face your enemy head on in this large-scaled-high-tech-land/air and navel weaponary pure destructive fun, this would have to be hands down one of the best i've played, even after the game has been out for so long, people are playing it everywhere today. So as far as you should play it or not? i think yes, yes you should play this game.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												My favorite RTS game standing alongside Dawn of War: Soul Storm.  It's very in depth and every faction is balanced fairly not to mention the units.  Each faction has a special little quirk to them that can be unlocked through research.  The Illuminate can build on water, the Cybran's navel units can walk on land, and the UEF can produce a flying aircraft carrier as well as a regular one.  There are lots of things that make each faction play differently.The campaign is very impressive and provides a good challenge as well as a great story (im my opinion).

												OK first of all I'm only recommending this game because it IS fun on it's own, but if you want a true sequel to supreme commander this is not it.  The battles are smaller and much less epic feeling than the originals, but to make up for this the units you do make are more important and custimizable through research. 												 I have only played this game in single player (crappy internet connection). I consider this the third instalment of Total Annihilation, with the next (4th) chapter being Planetary Annihilation. I have only recently bought the DLC infinite war and have noticed an increase in the aggressiveness of the AI, making it harder to defeat and adding replay value to the game.If you like RTS – then you should have this in your collection, along with Supreme Commander and Forged Alliance.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												This game, obviously has a different set up than SC1 and FA. It is a dumbed-down version of SC1. I would still recommend this game, it holds its own in the RTS world, but in many peoples' opinion, the new interface and engine doesn't compare to FA and SC1. I agree. I would recommend checking SC1 and FA before buying this game. One thing that most people find nice about this game, is the fact that the matches are usually shorter. Experimentals are much easier to get, but are also not as overpowered. I find this to be a nice setting because it leads to a slightly different change in gameplay then what SC1 and FA offered. All in all, a well-rounded game with a change of pace. If you're a fan of RTS, chances are you'll enjoy this one for a while. SC1=Supreme CommanderFA= Supreme Commander Forged Alliance

												Massive let down over the first. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 22, 2012
												Been a big Squaresoft gamer, since FFII on SNES.  Been a big Cavedog player, since Total Annihilation, the predecessor in the future timeline of the Supreme Commander series, when the wars were over and left nothing.  But war.  Played the demo and was not impressed with its mythological aproach/introduction to units of each faction.  When I got the game though, it was a whole 'nother story (quite literally!).  I enjoyed immensely the plotlines of each faction and their tie-in's.  It was done well, and the pacing was good on Normal difficulty.  I got my♥♥♥♥♥kicked on Hard at first.  Definitely toned down from Forged Alliance in terms of resource management, but shifts focus to the war effort and strategy without the constant monitoring of resource influx.  I love them all, and each version/sequel honestly stands alone.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2013
												If you're looking for epic battles, get SupCom 1. SupCom 2 is a step backward in many regards.  There are quite a few gambreakers (like aegis shields requiring manual regeneration, mass conversion being automated [having to select all your mass converters and pressing Alt+M every 6/20 seconds is not fun at all).The number of units has been downscaled. There is a research tree system now.  Experimentals are now a slightly larger unit rather than the awesome units they had been.Overall, it's not a bad game. It plays more like a Command and Conquer title on a larger scale (I like CnC).Get it for less than $10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												First-of-allSupreme Commander 2 isn't the prequel of Supreme Commander: Forged Allience!So, after we cleared that let's talk about Supreme Commander 2.Yes! Supreme Commander: Forged Allience is better then this one, of course it came after it but this one is still a really good RTS!Let's try to split this review into four parts.-Positive facts-Mixed facts-Negative facts-Personal AddsPositive facts-Supreme Commander 2 is the refined version of Supreme Commander where they tried new things and improved It. -This game works on a toaster, the game doesn't need much requiements and works pretty fluent on older PCs-It is easier, wich makes it more playable for newcomers and give playes that don't play RTS a game they can learn and love it.-This game is still "alive", this game is still getting played by 30k players in the last two weeks-It got a ("deep and powerful"-PC Gamer) story that is really intresting and exciting-It looks still good, you wont believe it but for a game that was released 2010, it's pretty-It has Multi-Monitor Support and got some pretty cool features like tactical maps on the one site of the monitor etc. that are really cool-It got a really fast and addicting gameplay, you can play for hours without even realising it-Got a tech-tree where you can upgrade your units and expand your arsenalMixed facts-It splited the Supreme Commander community into two smaller communities-Doesn't got something unique-A.I. have some problems with the movement but this doesn't happen oftenNegative facts-I am happy that I don't have to write something down for the negative facts because they isn't something gamebreaking or something very awful, but if you want someone to hate this game for some reason you can read the review from Geoff Hunt ->Review link[www.gamerevolution.com]<-Personal Adds-This game is one of the best RTS you can find nowadays but his sequel Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is better and cheaper.-This game is PERFECT for newcomers and people that hadn't play RTS-Games before and give them an easy and pretty cool game to playConclusion:->If you are new to the RTS genre, buy this game!->If you are familiar to RTS but want to have an easy game and want to "test" the SupCom Series, buy this game!->If you are familiar to RTS and want something challenging, buy Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance or better buy the Gold Edition so you can see what this and the newer game is based of.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												Supreme Commander 2: Supposed to be the continuation of the first title: Forged Alliance.As a "new" player in Supreme Commander 2, I completely agree with all the other negative reviews of the game, but I'll tell you more about something I have seen it's not covered.The maps are small because the developers decided it would've been a good idea to implement 4v4 matches in which 1 real life second lasts 4 or even 5. You end up having rounds that take 5 hours but should've took 1. All the system configurations are very good so it's not that, it's the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ communication system. Well done.Secondly, if you disconnect, you can't rejoin and you die. Yeah, this is a feature that you need.Third, path finding: You have air units, and you redirect their path a bit to the left to the arrival point? You better wait till they rotate 360°, which takes an immense amount of time especially with experimentals.Experimentals, more like useless pieces of standing or flying breads, besides the special buildings: They aren't even balanced, they cost less yes but they're really ♥♥♥♥♥♥..Even when they fall down.Fourth, Apparently two engineers can't work on the same thing at the same time.Fifth: I hope you don't like ground units, (Especially experimentals) because they're disgustingly slow. The only way to win is by spamming  normal bombers.Sixth: AI, for some reason their conversion rays have an immense range (Not kidding here), and they can still convert things underwater (Whilst I've read they shouldn't be able to)Seventh: There are like 1/4 of the units in FA.TL;DR: Looking for a good supreme commander game? Go for FA, yeah it's still laggy if you play in multiplayer (justified because it's an old game), but it's better.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
												     This game is a classic, and it surely was made during the dark age of RTS games, where strategy games were nearing extinction and after my favorite RTS base builder series got ♥♥♥♥ed over by removing bases.      All my units look like toys and ants, and the entire game feels pretty well thought out. Some of the amphibious units are amazing, and the projectile system is spectacular especially when it comes down to missles and artillery. They even got point defense and all the things that makes land/sea battles at an epic level.     I never played the origenal Supreme Commander, however there is enough single player content in this to satisfy the waning multiplayer community. I recommend it, dispite the publishers infamity that is wrongly placed on them since they don't make games, they only market and sell them using contracts that will screw a company over if they F up only once.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												This to date has to be the RTS I have played the most. I have replayed the whole campaign on a number of occasions. Also play skirmishes and multiplayer with my friends on a regular basis. It is quite a different game from SupCom 1 due to the way the research has been changed. But I think it makes for a faster paced game.Each side has its Pro's and Con's, lending themselves better to either your play style or the distribution of land & sea. Overall a fantastic game.My only real criticism is that there is no native map creator/editor. This is something the game sorely needs. If they released a new DLC which added a new storyline/maps and a map/scenario creator then TAKE MY MONEY!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 29, 2014
												Brillaint game. I know there was a lot of hate towards the game from some of the community because it was not set on such large maps as the previous game. But you get used to it pretty quick and it makes sense. It was never meant to be a direct clone but a step forward in design, graphics and performance. There are plenty of unique units (even more if you get the add-on pack) and a good single player experiance. Multiplayer for me was tough as there are too many really good hardcore players out there that could get hundreds of units while I still had no defense and olny a handfull of crap units. So I much prefered to play with me and a friend against the AI. The only down side for me is that there is no map editor and no new DLC. Hope one day the Dev's release a map editor.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												The game is not terrible in it's own rights. But the same can be said about Command and Conquer 4. If you have no idea what SupCom franchise is, and better yet are not that into huge strategy games, then getting SupCom2 is not a bad call. It's fast paced, it has cool units, and some interesting mechanics. For a heavy discount it is okay. But you know what is a better deal? Buying Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance. It's a standalone expansion to the original SupCom, and a pinnacle in the short lived franchise. The scale is epic, and does not compare to anything. 81x81km maps with orbital lasers, nuclear artillery with global range, and clashes of 500 units a piece? You bet. Forged Alliance is simply unique, and there is no game to date that managed to repeat the formula. SupCom2 is a bland, boring "we want to make a second Starcraft".Oh, and if you are into story based singleplayer, forget about SupCom2. It is absolute garbage. Get original SupCom instead (3 campaigns, 1 per race, all worth while)

												This is exactly how a sequel should be, at least in my opinion. It changes the game in the correct areas. It takes the base game and does a lot more than just upgrade the graphics or make minor changes. This sequel adds new strategic elements because the unit and structure progression is done in a different way. By getting this game you add to the SC experience, you don't replace it (if you own the first game that is, which you really should because it is awesome).I'm not really sure if this is better than the original but it kind of doesn't matter. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2015
												Supreme Commander 2 is the ultimate strategy game. It has an effective multiplayer skirmish system, and if you want to play by yourself, there is a reasonably good campain as well as a great AI battle skirmish. The maps are beautiful and gameplay is fairly simple to learn. Unit AI is not perfect, but that is to be expected to soem degree. The enemey AI are very good if you want them to be, but are still within the range of bing defeated, if you put a lot of time and effort into it. Getting forward in the campaign is harder than I think it should be, and there are multiple stages that you can see were mot as thought out. However, the storyline is pretty good, and is not nessesary to play.  Overall, I would give the game an 8.75 out of 10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												It's just so much sound and fury. There's a lot going on, but there's no real feel that I'm actually controlling anything besides clicking a bunch of buttons until I inevitability build up enough troops to just head to the only path towards the enemy and achieve victory through the barest planning and barest strategy. Comparrisons to the original are inevitable, if this game's pedigree didn't come from a solid history I wouldn't have gotten it . Mostly what I find distressing is how dumbed down and just ugly it looks to the original. On the surface they look similar, but the maps are tiny, confined and uninspired. The AI is lazily written where the enemy just sends a constant stream of the same enemies along the same path continiously. The plot...well the plot was serviciable in the first one, but in the sequel it's straight up offensive. For instance, how do you not know who a guy's wife is when you're planning a coup when said guy controls a giant mech with unlimited potential?At the end of the day, this feels more like a cash grab then a serious attempt at a game. At least I didn't pay full price.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 25, 2015
												I love the first part and the expansion pack. I played those a lot. And I really mean a lot. It is hard and the micromanagement is really necessary to rule the battlefield. In this sequel, this micromanaging option is gone. The game is more fast-paced. No need to build a strong economy. You just need to build some necessary buildings and you can create experimental units within 10 minutes. But it has a charm. :) The research trees are unique for every faction and every faction has it's own strengths and weaknesses, but the balance is great. It is more like a C&C, then Supreme Commander, but it's still good, especially the multiplayer with live opponents.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2016
												This game is insanely fun and awesome. If you like strategy games, you probably want to get this, I really enjoyed playing this game. It is great on just skirmish mode, but adding the campaign and complete story too, it was a nice addition. All three factions are fun to play with and the game is varely balanced. Its also pretty stable but from time to time, in a 4 hour session, it will crash, but only if you try spamming. Now putting aside how much I like this game and start being more like a critic. I say my final words, don't quote me on this(but I will)"The game is farely well made and has the basics down pretty good, it could have some changes done to it to make it better, and more like Forged Alliance but overall I recommened this game"(minelion1 1).
