number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Supreme Commander 2 is the successor to the critically-acclaimed Supreme Commander 1 and Supreme Commander Forged Alliance titles made by Gas-Powered Games and published by Square Enix.  In the distant future, wars will be fought not by hordes of manned armies but rather swarms of drones remotely commanded by people in giant robots in the battlefield for some reason. This toned down sequel has drawn either much praise or a lot of vitriol from its community.  With such mixed responses, one may wonder if this game is even worth playing, let alone looking at it.  This review hopes to answer that question (summary below):	-Story:  Being a game published by Square Enix, one would expect story to be the primary focus of the game, but it seems that even the story in SupCom2's case was toned down in comparison to its predecessor (even though it was enough for me to want to see what the end looked like).  Throughout the 18 campaign missions divided equally between the United Earth Federation (UEF), Aeon Illuminate and the Cybran Nations, the three factions struggle to keep a fragile alliance together from internal plots to thrust one side into power over all others.  While this may sound dramatic, the tone never gets too grim while also avoiding an overly idealistic view.  The main characters sound like interesting concepts, but they're all executed in an uninteresting way with monotonous speech and limited facial expressions.  It also doesn't help that the FMVs feel lacking and empty.  Despite these facts, the campaigns still provide the benefit of practice for the multiplayer community, at least enough to familiarize the player with each faction.  It's still recommended to practice in skirmish mode and within the multiplayer community itself though.  Whether you care about the story or not, the campaign is at least something to pass the time and learn about the game.  Score:  3/5    	-Graphics:  One of the main complaints voiced by fans of the previous Supreme Commander games is that the graphics in SupCom2 aren't nearly as spectacular as its predecessor.  While they aren't as bad as they could be, the presentation of the game is rather simple in a way that's almost lackluster in both unit and world design.  Even on the highest graphical capabilities, the game looks like something made out of legos almost.  The scaling is also a little strange, but it's understandable as to why the developers took this path:  They were betting on the idea that gamers in the start of the 2010's wouldn't be able to afford powerful computers with the best hardware on the market.   As a result, those whom had played the first game and eagerly awaited a new and improved sequel were disappointed while it didn't discourage newcomers from entering the franchise.  If you're the kind of person who doesn't care too much about graphics, this is the game for you.  If you wanted something even more realistic than the first, look elsewhere.  Score:  3.5/5	-Gameplay:  Another complaint by the fans of Supreme Commander 1 and Forged Alliance was that the gameplay was toned down in terms of complexity for SC2.  While Supreme Commander 2 is simpler than its predecessor in terms of strategic depth, this is not necessarily a bad thing.  The goal of the game is to assert your military supremacy with swarms of unmanned units while also avoiding total annihilation.  Units are constructed out of two resources:  Building Mass, and energy which is easier to harness since generators can be placed anywhere as opposed to mass extractors which are placed on strategic points and must be secured.  Instead of tiers, factions can invest research points that are accumulated over time to improve their units on the spot with increased gains in research the more research facilities are constructed.  Rather than requiring buildings dedicated to unlocking research though, one can just simply access their tech tree and spend points on what they can afford.  While this does sound better than the typical method of improving units, it can be tedious or outright absurd to feel the need to relearn upgrades every single game.  SupCom2 also benefits from allowing players to plan joint-operations with their land, naval and air units and the sheer size of one's armies, fleets and squadrons is still impressive with support up to as many as 500 units per team.  While some may complain about the downgrades given to each faction's late-game experimental units, they are still powerful enough to require planning to deal with effectively.  The view of the game is also impressive since not only is there a typical minimap with fog of war that's already drawn, players can zoom out and view the entire battlefield to coordinate multiple assaults in real time.  It may seem overwhelming at first, but it won't be take long to improve one's micro-management and multi-tasking skills.  To put it simply, if you're looking for a game with strategic-depth that's important for a long-term goal, play SupCom 1.  If you are more a fan for smaller-scale battles of tactics, SupCom 2 is the game for you.  Score:  4.5/5-Sound:  Even though it seems that sound wasn't a high-priority for Supreme Commander 2, there's still a small OST that might have been complimented if it only had more songs and influences from the kind of music heard in games like Hawken or Battletech.  There is a recurring leitmotif here that may be detected on and off, but is rather downplayed in contrast to everything else.  Fittingly, there is dynamic music in Supreme Commander 2 that shifts to match the intensity of the battle with almost nothing but wind at the start and a building orchestra that climaxes once the battles rage.  The warnings for this game only tells you of critical information that requires immediate attention such as “Nuclear launch detected” or “Commander under attack”.  The voice acting for the game feels mostly restrained, with lines alternating between hit-and-miss sarcastic remarks and attempts to add character development that fall flat most of the time.   Not much to say here, but it probably could have used something more.  Score:  3/5	-Replayability:  Despite the divided fanbase in regards to Supreme Commander 2 and its predecessor, SC2 still has hundreds of players in the multiplayer community.  The community hub is still fairly active, and there is a modding community for the game as well, just like the first game.  Even if you're not into multiplayer, Supreme Commander 2 has a campaign that would probably last the average player about a week or a week and a half to complete just for the regular objectives alone.  For completionists, there are also hidden objectives to discover in each campaign mission to improve one's score.  There is also skirmish mode which can be played against AI with misleading difficulty values.  Fortunately the game's AI opponents are relentless enough even on Normal to improve one's strategy and drive them to feel accomplished as they eventually defeat their opponents.  The good news is that this game will last a good while for fans of short-term RTS games.  Average life expectancy would probably be around a month just for the singleplayer alone and several for multiplayer if it still lives on.  Considering that the story ending on a cliffhanger that probably won't be answered any time soon, if at all, SC2 is in no danger of being replaced by a sequel unless a spiritual successor is developed.  Score:  4/5-Summary:  Supreme Commander 2 is the kind of game that's enjoyable in its own merits. If it weren't so conflicting with the lore, it's probably be more tolerable to SupCom 1 fans if SC2 could be thought of as a prequel in disguise as a sequel. If you aren't too judgmental about graphics or complexity and just wish to have a fun, futuristic short-term RTS, then Supreme Commander 2 is for you.  Overall Score:  18/25 or 72%.

What I expected to find was SupCom FA with better technical implementation. Instead, I got an incredible disappointemnt.If you liked SupCom 1, don't buy this game.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												The game is not terrible in it's own rights. But the same can be said about Command and Conquer 4. If you have no idea what SupCom franchise is, and better yet are not that into huge strategy games, then getting SupCom2 is not a bad call. It's fast paced, it has cool units, and some interesting mechanics. For a heavy discount it is okay. But you know what is a better deal? Buying Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance. It's a standalone expansion to the original SupCom, and a pinnacle in the short lived franchise. The scale is epic, and does not compare to anything. 81x81km maps with orbital lasers, nuclear artillery with global range, and clashes of 500 units a piece? You bet. Forged Alliance is simply unique, and there is no game to date that managed to repeat the formula. SupCom2 is a bland, boring "we want to make a second Starcraft".Oh, and if you are into story based singleplayer, forget about SupCom2. It is absolute garbage. Get original SupCom instead (3 campaigns, 1 per race, all worth while)

												After giving it some thought I can now do this review.Pros+ Runs pretty good+ Good variety of optionsCons+ Everything that made the original Supreme Commander has been removed or made generic+ Really crappy unit variety. + Story is .... meh+ Maps are smaller supporting only 6 players at max.+ Campaign is really short+ Tons of balancing issuesThe put it simply Square Enix dumbed down the game to secure a console release of the game.  Everything from the three tech stages to awesome experimentals has been taken out.  The core of what made the original Supreme Commander has been lost.  The unit variety is pretty pathetic. Most of the naval units have been stripped out, and the game seems to favour air combat for some reason.  The experimentals are even more pathetic, requiring only a small wave of tanks to take out (as displayed in the first mission).  Honestly avoid this game.  SupCom has become a shadow of its former self.

content:
Posted: March 16
												If you're a Command and Conquer fan, you'll like this game.If you're a Starcraft fan, you'll enjoy it for a bit.If you're a Supreme Commander fan, you won't like this game.  This is the main problem of this game: It's a fun RTS, but not a true Supreme Commander sequel.  The shallow, unfinished, and frankly, broken sequel fails to live up to what made the original so good.  It is fun, if you haven't played the first games or weren't a fan of how slow or convoluted they were, until you reach the problems of the game.  The engine can't support even the small amount of units you can pump out, the pathing is new and cool... but still broken and frustrating.  The maps are small, the units are unbalanced, the mod support is weak.  I could go on, but I'm tired of bashing on a good game.  It's just a disappointing end to a franchise that could have rivaled the likes of Command and Conquer.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 3, 2012
												If you like Supreme Commander and Forged Alliance, you probably didn't like Supreme Commander 2. If you didn't like Supreme Commander and Forged Alliance, you probably didn't play Supreme Commander 2. While criticized by fans of the first game and its expansion, Supreme Commander 2 still stands out among Real-Time Strategy Games as one of the finest and most fun in the genre.Keeping the zooming map, large-scale battles and massive unit cap from its predecessors, Supreme Commander 2 offers several new innovations of its own. With a better User Interface and snarky graphics, it uses less computing power and thus solving the problems of computer crashes and lags its predecessors were notorious for. The best innovation, however, has to be the introduction of a unifited tech tree where players can choose their paths of research and therefore various strategies that range from an experimental army to rushing for nukes.The co-op is simply fantastic.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												I'm an RTS fan. Overall the game the engrossing, but the campaign script is pretty banal, and annoyingly you can't skip the droning cut scenes. The voice acting is pretty bad. Not a good introduction to the game. 2/5 for the script and acting. 4/5 for the missions. Compared to something like Starcraft 2 the script seems to be written by teenagers.Gameplay-wise the units are quite varied. The research tree is mostly power-ups with odd units being researched. I didn't always get the sense that it really made much difference which order you chose research in. 3.5/5 for AI balance. 4/5 for general fun. 3/5 for strategy elements. Seems to be more about brute force, and unit balance, and once you learn that all the missions are pretty much the same in terms of build order and selection.Haven't played multiplayer. I suspect that is the strong point. I briefly played SC1 and that seems more challenging. I suspect this has been simplified to entice a wider audience, but it seems a little too bland. There is nothing quirky about the units, script. It is a polished RTS, but not a memorable one. I think that sums it up for me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												I started this series with Supreme Commander and then moved on to Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance. I've played thousands of fun and amazing hours of the first two games and it only took me a few hours to find the horrible flaws in this one.This game is nothing like either of the first two games in function or in spirit . It is an all around disappointment, with so many things changed for the worse. For example, build queues beyond your current resources (the ability to plan ahead) are gone. Units have been simplified and unit numbers reduced. The overall game has taken on the per-game-leveling mechanics as those seen in the Battle for Middle-earth II and Command and Conquer: Generals RTS games. Map sizes have been greatly reduced and the graphics are terrible: the units look like fisher price toys.Basically, if you've never played the series, this game will be overly difficult to learn for what you get back from it and if you're a huge fan, like me, you'll absolutely hate the changes they've made.One reviewer said something like "Chris Taylor has created a game that is, simultaneously, too simple for experienced players and too complicated for new ones". That about sums it up. This one should be nominated for "The Worst Sequel Ever" award.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2012
												While most argue that SubCom 2 doesn't measure up to it's predecessor and certainly not to Total Annihilation, I try to judge games on their own merits when I can and on it's own, SubCom 2 is a competent RTS. The story is far smaller in scale then the first game, following the stories of three childhood friends on different sides of a three-faction war. It's nothing to write home about, but it ties the missions together well and features a few good twists. More importantly, the game itself is very fun to play. It harkens back to an age where battles in RTS were more about sheer size and broad strategy instead of tactical rock-paper-scissors with everything being a hard counter to something else. If an RTS can keep me playing instant action modes because the actual gameplay was just that fun, I judge it a good game. I don't generally play against anyone in RTSes, but I'm sure it has value as a competitive game, again, probably not on the level of the first but nonetheless fun to play.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												"What's in a name?" is the main downfall for Supreme Commander 2.The game is a very potent RTS, streamlined and easier to understand, and for many aspects, it's a good thing!  The economy is more straight-forward, there's a good tech tree, and matches are action-packed!But, do I recommend this game?  NO.It suffers the same problems as almost any RTS sequel.  To improve on a series, you iron wrinkles out of your previous game, make it easier to learn, to understand, to play, and ultimately to enjoy for as many people as you can.  The same changes happened with Lord of the Rings : The Battle for Middle-Earth II, in my opinion:  Solid game, loved by many and in many ways, superior to the first game.  But as for SupCom2, it lost its soul.  They are maybe better games in the end, but also more generic experiences that they once were.So, SupCom2, great game, but bland.  It needed to be named something else, because this isn't Supreme Commander.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Total Annihilation is one of my favorite games of all time. I would say its probably in my top 5. So when Supreme Commander came out, it was like my childhood dream came true. When they announced a Supreme Commander 2, I was very excited to know it did well enough to produce a sequel. That is, until they started saying things like "unit upgrades" and that they were making it more "streamlined"Supreme Commander 2 is not a sequel to Supreme Commander. It is an attempt to make Supreme Commander more appealing to the masses by making it similar to more traditional RTS games like Starcraft or the C&C series. It has unit upgrades, they took the large choice of units and unit "tiers" and reduced it to 1 or 2 main infantry/tank units for each side. The Aeon no longer have naval units, they just use their land hover units. This is not Supcom streamlined, this is a regular RTS with the infinite zoom feature. The heart and soul of SupCom/TA is gone, its just an empty shell with something else inside it now.If you enjoy traditional RTS games, you may find this one interesting as the infinite zoom ability is a mechanic all RTS games should have.If you loved TA and SupCom, you will hate this. I bought it day 1 and I don't think I have ever regretted a game purchase as much as this game.

content:
Posted: March 16
												If you're a Command and Conquer fan, you'll like this game.If you're a Starcraft fan, you'll enjoy it for a bit.If you're a Supreme Commander fan, you won't like this game.  This is the main problem of this game: It's a fun RTS, but not a true Supreme Commander sequel.  The shallow, unfinished, and frankly, broken sequel fails to live up to what made the original so good.  It is fun, if you haven't played the first games or weren't a fan of how slow or convoluted they were, until you reach the problems of the game.  The engine can't support even the small amount of units you can pump out, the pathing is new and cool... but still broken and frustrating.  The maps are small, the units are unbalanced, the mod support is weak.  I could go on, but I'm tired of bashing on a good game.  It's just a disappointing end to a franchise that could have rivaled the likes of Command and Conquer.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												I'm an RTS fan. Overall the game the engrossing, but the campaign script is pretty banal, and annoyingly you can't skip the droning cut scenes. The voice acting is pretty bad. Not a good introduction to the game. 2/5 for the script and acting. 4/5 for the missions. Compared to something like Starcraft 2 the script seems to be written by teenagers.Gameplay-wise the units are quite varied. The research tree is mostly power-ups with odd units being researched. I didn't always get the sense that it really made much difference which order you chose research in. 3.5/5 for AI balance. 4/5 for general fun. 3/5 for strategy elements. Seems to be more about brute force, and unit balance, and once you learn that all the missions are pretty much the same in terms of build order and selection.Haven't played multiplayer. I suspect that is the strong point. I briefly played SC1 and that seems more challenging. I suspect this has been simplified to entice a wider audience, but it seems a little too bland. There is nothing quirky about the units, script. It is a polished RTS, but not a memorable one. I think that sums it up for me.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												I started this series with Supreme Commander and then moved on to Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance. I've played thousands of fun and amazing hours of the first two games and it only took me a few hours to find the horrible flaws in this one.This game is nothing like either of the first two games in function or in spirit . It is an all around disappointment, with so many things changed for the worse. For example, build queues beyond your current resources (the ability to plan ahead) are gone. Units have been simplified and unit numbers reduced. The overall game has taken on the per-game-leveling mechanics as those seen in the Battle for Middle-earth II and Command and Conquer: Generals RTS games. Map sizes have been greatly reduced and the graphics are terrible: the units look like fisher price toys.Basically, if you've never played the series, this game will be overly difficult to learn for what you get back from it and if you're a huge fan, like me, you'll absolutely hate the changes they've made.One reviewer said something like "Chris Taylor has created a game that is, simultaneously, too simple for experienced players and too complicated for new ones". That about sums it up. This one should be nominated for "The Worst Sequel Ever" award.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												Definitely one of the greatest if not the greatest RTS i've played. It's fun, not as micro heavy as the 1st one. 3 factions, tons of units and buildings from each nation. The battles are quite amazing, you can have up to 1000 units (buildings included) in the vanilla version. You can even disable some things if you want to in the match setup, for example you can disable artillery or nukes, air units, land units, naval units. This is useful when you want to have a game where you only have to focus on 1 thing. This game is quite challenging even in vanilla if you have everything enabled.Longest match i had was 5 hours. Also there is research system, which means that everything is not unlocked right away- this adds a nice additional strategic aspect to the game, makes you decide what you want to get first.I didn't care about the story much, but the gameplay is great. Strategy games never really made me hooked story wise, unfortunately. Story wasn't bad though, i just prefer building and obliterating enemies with my faction.Some people prefer the SC1 and FA, but i like this one a lot more.This game requires quite decent PC, after every player gets tons of units, game gets quite slow. It usually stretches the match by a lot. There is a mod that is being worked on atm, "Revamp 2.0", there is Alpha of it. They basically make new units and buildings, some are from SC1 and the economy system is modified a little. I highly recommend that mod if you are especially interested in ridiculously challenging AI. I struggle greatly against even Hard AI... They made everything harder to get, researching is a lot more important now. Everything is ♥♥♥♥ing expensive. But it is one of the best mods i've played. If you want a more extreme version of the game just get the mod too. Mod requires the DLC, but you should get the DLC too, why would you not get it.I will rate the game 10.0/10.0I got nothing bad to say about this game other than you should try Supreme Commander 1 and Forged Alliance so you can see if you like the micro style more or the macro one. SC1 is also even more strategic. These 2 games are completely different IMO.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												First-of-allSupreme Commander 2 isn't the prequel of Supreme Commander: Forged Allience!So, after we cleared that let's talk about Supreme Commander 2.Yes! Supreme Commander: Forged Allience is better then this one, of course it came after it but this one is still a really good RTS!Let's try to split this review into four parts.-Positive facts-Mixed facts-Negative facts-Personal AddsPositive facts-Supreme Commander 2 is the refined version of Supreme Commander where they tried new things and improved It. -This game works on a toaster, the game doesn't need much requiements and works pretty fluent on older PCs-It is easier, wich makes it more playable for newcomers and give playes that don't play RTS a game they can learn and love it.-This game is still "alive", this game is still getting played by 30k players in the last two weeks-It got a ("deep and powerful"-PC Gamer) story that is really intresting and exciting-It looks still good, you wont believe it but for a game that was released 2010, it's pretty-It has Multi-Monitor Support and got some pretty cool features like tactical maps on the one site of the monitor etc. that are really cool-It got a really fast and addicting gameplay, you can play for hours without even realising it-Got a tech-tree where you can upgrade your units and expand your arsenalMixed facts-It splited the Supreme Commander community into two smaller communities-Doesn't got something unique-A.I. have some problems with the movement but this doesn't happen oftenNegative facts-I am happy that I don't have to write something down for the negative facts because they isn't something gamebreaking or something very awful, but if you want someone to hate this game for some reason you can read the review from Geoff Hunt ->Review link[www.gamerevolution.com]<-Personal Adds-This game is one of the best RTS you can find nowadays but his sequel Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance is better and cheaper.-This game is PERFECT for newcomers and people that hadn't play RTS-Games before and give them an easy and pretty cool game to playConclusion:->If you are new to the RTS genre, buy this game!->If you are familiar to RTS but want to have an easy game and want to "test" the SupCom Series, buy this game!->If you are familiar to RTS and want something challenging, buy Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance or better buy the Gold Edition so you can see what this and the newer game is based of.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 13, 2015
												In all honestly, For those who have never played supcom 1 or forged alliance (nor own them),  I would not see you a fool to get this game, it does have some things going for it, like smoother graphics, faster pace (very good for multiplayer games), and they did add a little more flavor to commanders in places where it was non-existent.But what tears me straight toward saying "No, I would not recommend this game." is that it is a HORRID sequel compared to the two stars behind it. First we were graced with Supreme commander, which practically gave birth to the level of RTS we see so much of now (or surpassed in scale as Sins of a Solar Empire did). Forged alliance enhanced the graphics of supcom 1 and added a whole new faction that was mentioned several times in supcom 1, the seraphim, and a multitude of new units. Sins of a Solar Empire Rebellion and Supreme Commander: Forged alliance are literally the only two RTS games I play anymore, I am such a huge fan of them.I like many other fans of the series got this game expecting the same magic, but when I realized Square Enix was involved in this project and not THQ (A company who I later learned had essentially fallen apart on hard times). My heart sank slightly. It really hit rock bottom as I jumped in and started playing...I immediately walked into the campaign, and after seeing the sheer madness of the Forged alliance campaign.... I beat the Supreme commander 2 campaign in just a day or two... NOT a good start. The whole story lacked much of the attention grabbing that could be found in Supcom 1 and Supcom Fa, it seemed to just guide my hand the entire way like I was a child that didnt know what to do, RTS games shouldnt do that... EVER. I will give credit in that the story of supcom 2 did have a rich background like that in supcom 1 and supcom FA... but it seemed like I was playing in a game set in an alternate dimension rather than a game set not very long after the end of the seraphim threat... the only character from supcom 1 and FA that carried over at all, was Gustaf Brackman... a shame... especially since the end credits of FA showed QAI rebooting... so that bonus bit no longer fits in, further supporting my say that this game hardly lines up with being set after forged alliance. The story that takes place WITHIN supreme commander 2 was like a crap sequel to not one but two emmy nominated blockbusters (Supreme commander 1 and FA)Back to the gameplay for a moment. I do want to give the devs of this, and chris taylor, credit for keeping some little flair from the original two games, like the cybrans having ships that can walk on land, etc. But I dont know what was going on, either Chris Taylor had far less say in how this game was developed or he was on some sort of drug when he was working on it. There is extremely little reason to ever use naval units as there is such a lack of variety of them from what I recall. Naval units weren't the only thing lacking, as there was a sense of emptiness in the manner of units, so all I ever ended up doing was nuking AI or spamming so many of a single unit that it didn't matter AT ALL what the AI did, they would get annihilated, even with the considerably smaller max amount of units compared to the first two games. The experimentals don't even look like they would hold up against their prequel counterparts, the Megalith II looks like a baby scorpion compared to the Megalith I, which outsized the monkeylord (which I WILL crack a smile that they put into this game as DLC.). When using them in supcom 2, they feel ludicrously more fragile than their supcom 1 counterparts, which i don't see the reason for really considering that in supcom 1 and FA you could easily take them out by just spamming what they are weakest against... (for galactic colossi, GUNSHIPS... LOTS OF GUNSHIPS).What hit the final nail of the coffin for me was research..... just.... WHY? What is the point if i don't get to use everything in the research tree? WHY DID YOU NOT KEEP THE UPGRADE SYSTEM THAT WORKED SO PERFECTLY!?If you want a great RTS for multiplayer though, I WOULD recommend this SOLELY for multiplayer... otherwise... AVOID THIS GAME.

content:
Posted: May 14, 2015
												I love this game, but there are a few things holding it back. Mainly when it starts to slow down, I just played an almost 2 hour game with AI and the actual time was only 45 min. When compared to other RTS games this one is my definite favorite. You can't have huge battles and artillery shells just flying in others but in Supreme Commander you can! Launching nukes is so much fun but can be infuriating when the anti nukes come online. The Commanders and units are so cool and you can have epic battles on this game. But the main thing again is when it starts to slow down, it's unbearable. But if you like any RTS this game is awesome and will make a great addition to your library. However you should also consider Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance, the Prequel to this game if you don't want the slowdown. (I'm still looking into how to combat the lag after awhile.)It doesn't slow down if you have Sorian AI and other mods installed. Plus there is a strong community behind that is very active and patches the game years after it's release. Supreme Commander is a good game if you don't have the slowdown and is very fun to play with friends.Also the soundtrack is pretty good for those tense moments when it's either win or lose!

content:
Posted: April 29, 2015
												One of the best RTS games I've ever played, Supreme Commander 2 brings a lot to the table. Where most RTS games bring a unit cap of 14, 150, or 200, Supreme Commander 2 brings a whopping 500. The scale of this game is amazing. From tiny Titan Bots to the collosal King Kriptors, this game is sure to wow you by how big the units are, and how many can fit on a screen without lagging. Of all the games in my Steam library, I find myself coming back to this one the most (almost 80 hours). The campaign is very fun and the characters are all very solid. The online is great, and even single player skirmish matches seem to never grow stale with all the different map options. All three factions feel very well balanced with every unit being weak to one unit or another, however, the 500 unit cap makes for very intense and interesting battles. If you don't already own this game, buy it now. you won't regret it.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												An excellent game by an excellent company, Gas Powered Games, that has unfortunately been disolved by another company (Wargaming.net). It has plenty of maps, units, and strategy to keep you entertained for a long time. Important to keep in mind is that the game is designed to be more worried about the big decisions and less about the little ones. Infinite Queueing, Infinite zoom, a straight forward resource collection method lend this game to be far from Starcraft 2, the other SC2. If micromanagement is your thing, this game likely won't be as interesting to you as Blizzard's RTS, but that doesn't diminish the fact that this game can scale to epic proportions, with a fun design and great battles.Mind that multiplayer will be staggered, as the game has been released for a while. Great campaign though, if cliched.I've put a lot of time into this game, and I don't regret a minute of it. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												In a certain way the naysayers about this game are right; Gas Powered Games had to put their knees on the ground just to get Supreme Commander 2 made. They had to make several compromises to make it run on a console as well. Yet, even with the limitations that Square-Enix (publisher and IP-owner) imposed the developers have made the most out of SupCom 2 on PC. While reduced in scope/options compared to Supreme Commander and Forged Alliance (FA) this sequel certainly has its value. It's more performant, it's flashier with graphical effects, has faster gameplay and it also offers several interesting unit/experimental ideas. The new research tree is easy-to-use although it does make you lose (track of) the game sometimes because you and your enemies are making hard choices which are not always immediately clear until it's too late. It's less about a long and constant war on all fronts (like in SupCom and FA) and more about picking the right front to fight on. Going for a jack-of-all-trades way of researching isn't going to win you any games. The whole experience is great fun nonetheless, and that generally in a lot less game time than a regular SupCom or Forged Alliance session usually demands. Three factions make for nice variation though just as before you don't have to expect as much differences between these sides as StarCraft offers. The overall experience doesn't suffer though as you have more (broad macro) tools to fight a futuristic war here.A reasonable campaign and stock standard skirmish play options don't sound too thrilling but especially in the latter part (skirmish) Supreme Commander 2 really comes together. The AI is quite decent (thanks to modder-turned-developer Sorian working at GPG at the time) and the selection of maps worthwhile. A fair share of updates made the game not lose its edge and the Infinite War Battle Pack DLC is frankly a no-brainer to buy alongside the main game. I wouldn't say the multiplayer balance is perfect, not a lot of online players present too. Same case for mods, don't expect something as vibrant as with the original game, let alone the total mod craze of Total Annihilation. If you want a quick and spectacular romp of RTS fun in (co-op) skirmish play, you can't go wrong with this. It's not the SupCom 2 some would have liked to see but it's clear by now that several publishers didn't believe in a second addon for the original SupCom (which was originally the plan) nor a true sequel that would be as big in scope. SupCom 2 as we know it is the best alternative we got in the end. If you want something more complex then there is still always the active Forged Alliance Forever effort. That ultimate next-gen all-out-sci-fi-war simulator will have to wait I am afraid until the RTS genre makes a big comeback...

												epic strategy game, hundreds of ways to challenge yourself. Try to cross a canyon without an air force, dominate a water map without a navy. Send an endless horde of tanks, assault bots, fighters, bombers, and ships to pick away at your enemy's base or send in massive experimental units to decimate entire armies. If you don't like fighting up close and personal, use massed artillery emplacements to rain death down on known enemy locations or use strategic missles to scout the map through nuclear fire. With the number of different maps, possible restrictions that can be put in place, and the three sides, the only limit to the number of ways you can win is your imagination.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2015
												Supreme commander 2 is a more stream line version of its predecessor with enthuses on malty player and speed. Most negative comments on this game have been focus on lack of continuity to its predecessor and its approach to streamlining the proses. However judging the game soul on its merits and excluding its franchise. One is able to state it is a top contender for an RTS.Skirmish:The game attempt to streamline and simplify the tech tree, building and units by eliminating a lot of low tear early game tech (which became obsolete one’s high tear was researched witch plagued is predecessor) favouring a more late game play style. Buildings and units may feel homogeneous at first however the game really picks up ones you have unlock a few mid to upper tear tech.
